title: Unmasking your online reality - Youth Artist in residence

milestone.title: Youth Zone
milestone.description:
**Space description**
For our collective sake
Let your passion create a story
Let your passion design the day
Let that passion fight the cause
Let our voice be heard

The Youth Zone is like a poem—creative, unexpected, powerful. Join this space for youth leaders and their mentors who are creating art, technology and positive social change. From a Raspberry Pi-coded singing potato to our fireside chat on Internet health, come explore our collective tomorrow.

body:
**[ UUID ]** d3886469-551b-4735-938f-14c047880222

**[ Session Name ]** Unmasking your online reality
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sally Trivett
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Arts Award





### What will happen in your session?
Making use of tactile, arts based materials, participants will be invited to 'unmask their online reality'.Social Media plays a huge role in who we are, both on and off the web, and through the creation of an art instillation who we are on and offline will be presented. Using plain white masks as the template, we're asking attendees to deface their mask using Sharpie markers, creating a version of the identity they aim to portray online. Then, with permission, they will be filmed in 3D wearing the mask (a simple 360 headshot), the the aim to include both digital imagery (as immersive an VR experience of others' identities) and each mask in a physical art instillation/group exhibition.  

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Highlight to attendees and MozFest community the extent to which we reconstruct our reality online, provoking thought. Discuss whether this is a good thing. If we always portray how we want to be seen, and whether the relative anonymity of this, coupled with the pressures of social media, changes how we interact. instillation and group exhibition - highlights a sense of community, bringing together the best intentions of identity online, and identity through face-to-face interaction. I hope to create a fun and inclusive space for all to share their thoughts and get creative, a skill valued across all sectors, whilst provoking thoughts and questions about the pressures social media place upon an individual and their reactions to that.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Sharpie permanent markers in a variety of colours, a number of plain white masks with elastics for hanging, a space to hang the masks and a means to do so (I can however work this out on the day if necessary). Tables and chairs, 360 degree camera, HTC Vive/google cardboard.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

body:
**[ UUID ]** b13dd996-7826-46e1-97eb-1d86c8fe295c

**[ Session Name ]** Salvage Instaltion 
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Babitha  George
[ Additional facilitators ] Nikhil Nambiar,






### What will happen in your session?
The Khadi movement in India was framed as a non-violent protest against foreign control of the economic, cultural and artistic lives of the people. For Gandhi, western economics was a devastating negation of the spiritual identity of an Indian. Self-sufficiency was articulated as an attempt to wrest control from the dominant force of the time – the British empire. However, the spirit of self-sustenance went beyond the rejection of the foreign. Gandhi had a radical and nuanced view of what constituted the Indian nation, that many would now consider not only unviable but perhaps also dangerous. Gandhi insisted that the state empower villages to remain independent economic entities, with local production aligned with local consumption.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Understanding of craft as a way of making change



### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ Session Name ]** Ding! A magazine on the internet and things
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Pete Thomas






### What will happen in your session?
Welcome to the first issue of DING, a magazine about the Internet and things. We founded this magazine because we saw a gap in the practice of slow, considered making and the breakneck speed of technology. We wanted to anthologize the sprawling online conversations and provide a place of reflection for people interested

in crafting technology in more responsible ways. It is our place of refuge to discuss internet health and emerging technologies - slowly, sustainably and in print.

Our inaugural issue focuses on craft.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To showcase the stories, value and people behind this new publication from the Open IoT Studio


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.

All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

An ambitious digital artwork across an app, an interactive web platform and a series of public art works about finding space for reflection, expression and connection in our daily lives, creating a year of connections between India and the UK. Share the experience of making the installation and where it can go next

**[ UUID ]** eafbd6a8-2a90-4a3a-adfe-b3704bab580d

**[ Session Name ]** Prototyping Futures
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Martin Skelly
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Open IoT Studio / University of Dundee
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @mskell

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Loraine Clarke, Florian Merz, and Beth Spowart


### What will happen in your session?
In this session, we will discuss the value of physical objects for telling stories around emergent technologies, debate best practice for creating objects that can raise awareness of an issue, and sketch out ideas for how prototyping could add value to your work area or projects. The session will utilise findings from creating prototypes that the Open IoT Studio recently created around IoT & Voice, and a student collaboration between the Mozilla Foundation and University of Dundee exploring Future Camera interfaces.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Often the issues and debates we need to engage members of the public in around technology are complex. We will discuss best practice for creating prototype objects and experiences that encourage critical conversations and debate around a topic or problem with diverse non technical audiences.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
NA


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Learning to Discern: Mapping Citizen Strategies to Combat Misinformation & Propaganda
body:
**[ UUID ]** 90c006d1-ef67-485c-9eb7-18f1eeb8fcfe

**[ Session Name ]** Learning to Discern: Mapping Citizen Strategies to Combat Misinformation & Propaganda 
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Mehri  Karyagdyyeva
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** IREX 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @MehriKar

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Katya Vogt 


### What will happen in your session?
We’ll start with a 15-minute overview of work we’ve done in conflict-affected areas of the Ukraine, which focused on building resilience to misinformation through thoughtful exposure to debunking and fact-checking. We’re particularly interested in strategies that don’t tell people which media to consume, but rather teach how to watch, read, or listen in order to avoid manipulation toward hatred.

The remaining 45 minutes will focus on session participants selecting a few countries they want to hone in on

The state of disinformation and propaganda, externally and internally 
At-risk issues and topics
Manipulation tactics 
“Personas” that represent common media and information consumption patterns
“Demand-side” media literacy approaches that might fit each audience and context — especially those that can be embedded into daily life 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
An emerging map of countries that face influx of disinformation 
A better understanding of how to maximize and coordinate supply- and demand-side solutions for various populations being targeted by propaganda and fake news
Advancing an evolving toolkit of potential practical solutions that not only “preach to the choir” but have the potential to reach and change behaviors among of typically reluctant audiences 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Facilitation supplies such as markers, flipchart papers, sticky notes. 
Projector.  
1 laptop (we can provide if needed).



### Time needed
60 mins

**[ UUID ]** 114df9df-c402-4398-bb09-3a20618df5a1

**[ Session Name ]** DING: Talks about the internet and things
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jon Rogers
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Open IoT Studio
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @ileddigital

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Pete Thomas


### What will happen in your session?
We'll discuss DING, a magazine about the Internet and things. We founded this magazine because we saw a gap in the practice of slow, considered making and the breakneck speed of technology. We wanted to anthologize the sprawling online conversations and provide a place of re ection for people interested in crafting technology in more responsible ways. It is our place of refuge to discuss internet health and emerging technologies - slowly, sustainably and in print.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Today we live with digital technology that’s primarily manufactured in Shenzhen and designed in Silicon Valley. Centralization of production means that there is less choice and less inclusion. We need decentralized ecosystems, where craft thrives so that people can deploy the materials around them to make local solutions that last a long time. We hope you enjoy this session and that it sparks ideas for crafting technology in healthier ways.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
N


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Using Advanced Web Technologies to Address Threats to the Health of the Internet

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** d256df4d-9a38-4841-b17a-5894205bb645

**[ Session Name ]** Using Advanced Web Technologies to Address Threats to the Health of the Internet
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ruth Nicholls
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Ravensbourne


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Tor-Arne Njamo,Amy Jackson-Bruce


### What will happen in your session?
Students studying at Ravensbourne for a BA in Web Media have been supported by the Mozilla Foundation to explore their recent Internet Health Report, research one or more of the identified threats to the health of the internet and use advanced web technologies to tackle those threats. This could involve using technologies such as web VR, AR or the internet of things to advocate for a healthier internet or mitigate against identified threats. The session would be an interactive workshop, initially diving into the key challenges identified in the Internet Health Report and then showcasing the best student responses.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of the session is for the students and attendees to have a deeper understanding of how technologies hosted on the web can be harnessed to make the web itself healthier. Whilst new web technologies are exciting to play around with, this session aims to show that they can be harnessed to take society a step closer to having an internet that is more open and accessible for all.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
None


### Time needed
less than 60 mins

title: Designing Network-Centric Resources

### What will happen in your session?
 In this session we will look at what it takes to design resources that are people powered and participatory, and support the sharing and dispersal of knowledge within networks and communities. We will examine methodologies for sharing ownership, enabling contribution and supporting collaboration. We will also share lessons learned from existing network-centric resources such as Wikipedia, Tor and LevelUp. Participants will also have an opportunity to learn about and join a growing network of resources developers

title: Do we live in a world where inclusion is for all?

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

body:
**[ UUID ]** 5844f0dd-e29b-4ff3-95cd-6d310504e0a3

**[ Session Name ]** Do we live in a world where inclusion is for all?
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Hannah Prentice






### What will happen in your session?
Start of session, I will introduce myself and speak bit about my background [living with Tourettes] and why I am here today. Set them a task to work in pairs/groups of three, to discuss the topic inclusion for all [how can we support everyone in society to have a voice even if they might struggle in day to day life with this]. Plan how they will present it through an accessible artform. They go and explore the space at Mozilla fest, gather any evidence/inspiration to then on to creating, this will take the longest. I would assist anyone that needs ideas or help. Final part is a group presentation back about their piece, explain why they have created this piece.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
In the session, participants create pieces of artwork that publish online/put up artwork around different of spaces of Mozilla Fest to display. The artwork topic is [“How can we enable everyone to express their reasonable voice without fear of retaliation”]. Do we live in a world where inclusion is for all? I will give examples to suggest idea for the artwork, like drawings, poetry recording small soundbites, interviewing a person, collage, typography, stenciling.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

title: Artist Open Studio + Archana Prasad

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

title: Artist Open Studio + Paolo Cirio

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

title: Artist Open studio + Xiao Mina

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

For our collective sake
Let your passion create a story

Let that passion fight the cause
Let our voice be heard

body:
**[ UUID ]** be8d83d8-2a43-445a-a0d3-2ba7a412aed3

**[ Session Name ]** Finding Fantastic Mr (fire)Fox | Build your own Pi-powered camera trap
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Alasdair Davies
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Arribada Initiative & Naturebytes
**[ Submitter's Github ]** al2ka

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Michael Sunbury,Jon Rodgers,Stephen Mowat,Jon Fidler


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will start exploring how technology is used to monitor, track and understand wildlife movements by professional conservationists, with a hands-on look at actual sensors and cameras currently used to monitor arboreal species in the Amazon rainforest, watch penguins live in Antarctica, and track sea turtles off the coast of Africa. After the introduction, we'll introduce British wildlife to the audience and highlight how they can personally use technology too to monitor and assess wildlife in their own back gardens. We'll then explore how to build a DIY Naturebytes Wildlife Cam Kit (Pi-powered) and invite participants to build and deploy their own camera the same evening (that we will provide) to try and discover if there are urban foxes nearby.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Inspire the MozFest audience to use their digital making skills, often as a family, to aid the conservation of native wildlife here in the UK by using accessible technologies such as the Raspberry Pi and camera module to help assess wildlife populations. The evening event will also be family friendly, with a flask of tea and a chat outdoors whilst we deploy the cameras to highlight what else they may spot.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will bring example sensors for participants to explore and will provide a limited number of Naturebytes Wildlife Cam Kits for the evening event workshop building them.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 8f4cd947-7aab-4083-93b7-9dbe27eec1e7

**[ Session Name ]** What we love matters.
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sacha Judd



**[ Additional facilitators ]** TBC two London based digitally skilled fans


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will be introduced to the world of internet fandoms, a digital sub culture where individuals learn and develop amazing skills by making things about their passions. They will be asked to consider how the subject content of these forums and sites contributes to the feelings involved with imposter syndrome - people with skills devaluing themselves because they don't feel their work is valid. The second part of the session, participants will be asked to create something about something they currently love or used to when they were a child - from a simple meme to a digital masterpiece. We'll celebrate the joy of making.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To get people to reconsider the skills of those around them and to value the talents they have taught themselves in the process of making things that they are passionate about. A whole section of the web exists, yet is kept separate from the 'serious side of things' purely through thematic biases. Digital inclusion is about making the web somewhere to celebrate and shout about skills, to share ideas and to be welcomed, regardless of what you think is cool or not. An online gallery will be created for MozFest attendees to share what is important to them.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Access to something to make on or with.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 9c839019-f091-4c57-bf1f-c110a76a55ad

**[ Session Name ]** How an Emoji Becomes and Emoji
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jennifer Lee
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Emojination
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @jenny8lee




### What will happen in your session?
How exactly does an emoji end up on your phone keyboard? It's actually a tightly regulated process overseen by the Unicode Consortium, the non-profit organization based in Silicon Valley whose members are primarily US tech companies. It takes upwards of 18 months between when an emoji is proposed and when it can end up on your smartphone. A member of the Unicode Emoji Subcommittee and founder of Emojination will walk through the emoji proposal process, including the timelines, and the selection factors involved. Using successful proposals — including the DUMPLING emoji, as well as hijab emoji — the speakers will explain the dos and dont's of the process.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our aim is for people to understand the emoji proposal process, and feel empowered by it. Ideally we'll have folk who will be part of the "normal folks" who write emoji proposals — which is the equivalent of writing a very detailed high school lab report.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.



### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 35fa315e-e23d-4f5d-9d8f-5cf10b6d0b18

**[ Session Name ]** Alternate views of Internet Health
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Michael Saunby
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Exeter
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @msaunby

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Tanguy Denonain,J. R. Carpenter,Juliane Kahl,Kate Sicchi


### What will happen in your session?
The health of the Internet matters, the health of our planet matters, the heath of our democracies matter, young people need to be engaged in decisions about their future, yet the experts appear to disagree on what is to be done.

Internet access means more people than ever have access to the information they need to make important decisions, but true engagement appears to be lower than ever.  Maybe there is just too much information, too much disagreement, too many decisions to be made.

If we didn't remove ourselves from decisions about climate change, about internet privacy, about so many matters, how would we cope? Would our emotions take over, would we sob, or scream, or fight, or hide?



### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
What if we view our world through a different lens? In this session we will meet artists and student who have collaborated to create pieces which expose fears and dreams of the future of the Internet.

Explore how emotions, prejudices, experience and in-experience shape our collective vision of the Health of the Internet.

This will be enabled through discussion both of the works created during the accompanying MozFest Fringe Event at Exeter University and the process by which the works were created. 



### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 213d82e8-7ba2-465f-9c0d-83454ab66b52

**[ Session Name ]** Decolonizing the Net
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Collette Watson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Free Press
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @collettewatson

**[ Additional facilitators ]** 


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will learn how communities across the global Black diaspora are wielding the internet to counter false narratives and spark change IRL. From Brazil to South Africa, the United States to United Kingdom, individuals of African descent are innovating online campaigns and tools with very real implications. They are organizing civic power, amplifying underrepresented stories, shutting down problematic institutions and leading the way in online-to-offline change.

This session will explore examples of resistance and advocacy campaigns, as well as the data and technology that define them, and how these initiatives are shifting anti-Blackness.
Participants will spend the final 30 minutes brainstorming a certain type of anti-Black dynamic that is prevalent in their community, then producing ideas for oppositional online campaigns or tools.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of the Decolonizing the Net session will be for participants to learn how digital campaigns and platforms geared toward dismantling anti-Blackness have formed, evolved and flourished around the world.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector with audio speakers and monitor or projection screen
Five easels (5)
Flipchart paper
Markers



### Time needed
90 mins

title: Dance and Coding

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 13ef8ed6-1b50-497c-8e3d-042ea43df22c

**[ Session Name ]** Dance and Coding 
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Rebecca Evans
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Pell Ensemble 


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Lubomila 


### What will happen in your session?
Introduce students to elements of computational thinking and programming principles through dance and physical computing.

This 60 minute session will be movement based and is for any level of dance and or computing skills. We will introduce and begin to understand instruction, looping and selection through creating a dance sequence in groups. We then introduce lights already coded in Crumble that change according to audience interactions  that change the colour of the light. Each group of students will then take their movement sequence created and make it reactive to the different colour outcomes of the light that the audience is controlling.

Example: Jump when the light is green, stop when the light is red, continue
movement sequence when the light is off.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to make coding accessible by introducing it through movement.  We approach it in two different ways, one through creating a group movement sequence and the other by becoming performers that are controlled by an audience through technology.  In both cases the participants begin to understand:
-the need to be specific with instruction (by writing or 'coding' a dance movement and testing this on another group)
-rule vs sequence based instructions by choreographing or 'coding'  their movements
-different looping possibilities by choreographing or 'coding' movement
-selection and looping by reacting to changing lights that the audience controls.  
-testing, discussing and making improvements  


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Our requirements will be to have a large clear space where up to 35 people can move freely (10m x 10m) ideal.  We will bring all other equipment and will only require a couple plug points.  


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Exploring privacy in virtual reality: Porton Down

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 34fb038d-17ae-41d7-93d7-a6135a3bcd0c

**[ Session Name ]** Exploring privacy in virtual reality: Porton Down
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Callum Cooper






### What will happen in your session?
 This project will put the user into a sensationalist Virtual Reality game where their intimate data is not only presented but used against them.

The participant is encouraged to do a series of cognitive tests. Once the the first series of cognitive tests is completed the benevolent voice congratulates the subject/player and announces the next level. The subject repeats each test but now the VR systems manipulates their perception. This manipulation is hallucinatory in it’s nature. The user/players senses are increasingly distorted. 

By the final level, the tests descend into absurdity where the user/player is unable to achieve what should be a simple task.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To entertain, and to create debate and discussion around the unexplored topic of privacy within virtual worlds.

When completed, users receive a visualisation of all the data that has been collected throughout the subject/players engagement with the game. The report not only lists information about their physical body such as height and arm length but also more invasive information about their movement in the space during the game. The report also presents their level of engagement, concentration, agility and things that they have said with a sentiment analysis. Each of the user/players results are anonymously compares to each other. This report also gives a list all the data points that can be mined by VR systems. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will provide our own HTC Vive system.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:

An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. body:
**[ UUID ]** 5a7d2bab-20c6-4f4b-94ae-ad1480fbce82

**[ Session Name ]** Open data-driven storytelling
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Tomas Petricek
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Alan Turing Institute
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @tpetricek




### What will happen in your session?
This interactive session will discuss ideas that we developed as part of The Gamma project (https://www.turing.ac.uk/research_projects/the-gamma). The attendees will create a number of visualizations based on public data sets and we will discuss best ways of presenting data and engaging with the audience in order to make facts matter.

The session will consist of three parts:

1. A brief demo of some of ways of exposing and visualizing data via The Gamma (http://thegamma.net).
2. A hands-on part where attendees choose one of the provided data sets (or a custom one) and build their own visualizations.
3. A more general discussion about how accessible and engaging data science can restore trust in statistics and facts.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Governments and journalists publish increasing amounts of raw data, but at the same time, “post-truth” has been chosen as the word of the year 2016 and the general public increasingly distrusts statistics. In other words, data science has new capabilities to help us understand the world, yet it is becoming less relevant in public discussion. This session will seek to answer the question: **What can we do to make facts backed by data more accessible and engaging?**


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
No additional needs beyond a projector.


### Time needed
60 mins

Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 650a2a59-2633-4805-9db1-9e3a5acb31cd

**[ Session Name ]**  Fashion Hacktivism for a ‘Responsive Design Practice'
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Juliane Kahl

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @JulianeKahl

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Kristina Thiele


### What will happen in your session?
The Fashion Industry is the 2nd most polluting industry in the world, which exploits its workforce on a massive scale. The biggest challenges within Fashion in developing countries are inputs for manufacturing such as zippers. This session challenges the issue of the zipper by experimenting and customising. Participants will get the opportunity to create prototypes that are innovative, tech-related, extraordinary or just geeky and fun. 
They will leave the session with a self-made object, f.e. a sewn bag with a closure system, which could be a 3D print on the fabric.
Participants will be involved in a disruptive and participatory design process within Fashion. It will be demonstrated, that such an approach can be applied to many different areas.




### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Throughout this session, Fashion is an example of an empowering and sustainable disruptive design practice, which can facilitate change in emerging countries through applying a lean method. 

This challenge has been addressed at the first Fashion Hackathon in East Africa, in December 2016, as part of a postgraduate research project at London College of Fashion.

This event turned out to be a very efficient and productive participatory design process. 

By taking part in this Fashion Hackathon in Addis Ababa, the participants felt liberated of any design rules and norms. 

Their 'responsive, frugal innovation design approach' was supported by Open Source knowledge. Their mind-set became unlimited on how to come up with possible solutions for any pressing problem and issue.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
3D printer

Laser cutter

Fabrics

Materials

Cardboard

Sewing Machine


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Rolling back the ad-dependency, funding content peer-to-peer

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** 5483ab94-88e3-483c-9417-69014c786187

**[ Session Name ]** Rolling back the ad-dependency, funding content peer-to-peer
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Laura Dornheim
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Flattr (eyeo)


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Linus Olsson


### What will happen in your session?
We will give a brief introduction about the development from truly free content in the very early days of the internet to the wide-spread ad-dependency that funds online content today. Subscription models are technically and privacy-wise a better option but impose massive hurdles (and cost) to users. 
Flattr is a system that allows everyone on the web to make and / or receive small payments for the content they publish / consume. 
We want to discuss with the MozFest participants how such a system can become successful and how less "internet-affine" web users can be brought on board.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want to further educate about the negative impacts of the dependency on advertising not only in journalism, but all across the web, email-providers, dating sites, YouTube channels...
From the discussion, we expect valuable feedback about alternative funding models and how they can become succesful.
We will collect the feedback and make it accessible to all participants.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Users with devices (preferably laptops) will be sufficient!


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 94f9face-4136-4a31-9b45-aa25084e8387

**[ Session Name ]** Data-Based Digitally Inclusive Storytelling for Communities to Counter Incomplete or Incorrect Narratives in the Media
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Connie Moon Sehat
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Global Voices
[ Submitter's Github ] @connieimdialog






### What will happen in your session?
We will share a new element to Rising Voices' digital inclusion work through a new collaborative project with NewsFrames. In our pilot project, we will show how we have been working side-by-side with indigenous communities in Ecuador to collaboratively analyze data generated from the Media Cloud platform to better understand whether the narratives found in the media about these communities or issues important are being portrayed, misrepresented or ignored altogether. In addition, we have been working closely with these communities to model a new type of storytelling working with them to produce their own digital media responding to these data-based findings. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We would like attendees to have a better understanding how data can play a role in storytelling by marginalized communities. (example: https://newsframes.globalvoices.org/2017/07/22/in-the-depths-of-the-ecuadorian-amazon-digital-communications-aid-the-process-of-self-determination/) By sharing a concrete example of how we have been working with our pilot project communities through outreach, data analysis, and training, attendees will determine how a similar model may work with communities with whom they work. Following the presentation, we will provide plenty of time to invite feedback from attendees to help discuss challenges in this model or identify opportunities for creating a curriculum that can be utilized by others both as a self-guided or directed resource. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector + wifi


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Wearable Tech Innovation
body:
**[ UUID ]** 51f0d0dd-c75e-4d24-97b1-d9e53dce18d6

**[ Session Name ]** Wearable Tech Innovation
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Rachel Wong
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Konichiwakitty





### What will happen in your session?
I started learning about electronics in March 2017. I am a stem cell scientist currently doing a PhD to understand congenital blindness. Many children I've met have been awe to know that you can be a complete nerd/geek but still be fashionable. I would like to share my work and background to inspire children to pursue STEM careers, but also want to open the pathways towards cross-disciplinary research (science, tech & art). I am looking to reveal my konichiwakitty e-fashion collection of at least 5 complete outfits (including accessories like gloves, hats, bags, umbrellas, jewellery and shoes) on the day. Perhaps a fashion show might be more attractive but I would need to recruit some human beings!

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This is the first time I will be showcasing my entire collection so I'd like to be able to do it at the Science Fair on Friday. I think it's the best environment for people to come up and ask questions and have a more personal one-to-one conversation. I hope that wearable tech will gain more exposure and through this i could get some funding to expand my collection and ideas. I wish to break the stereotype and show the younger generation that you can be intelligent and also fashionable. Besides that, I also want to show that you can do anything you like (and more than one thing at a time) if you really have the passion for it.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I would require some (5 or less) mannequins or a clothes rail to put up my wearable tech/clothing. Also some tables to display my electronic accessories would be great. If the admin deciding committee thinks that a fashion show would be the best idea, I will try to request for models via the social network but might need additional help finding 5 ladies of size UK8/10. 


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: [PLACE HOLDER] Why do you need my fingerprint so I can buy rice?: Aadhaar in India as a case study

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jochai Ben-Avie
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @melechuga

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Melissa Romaine


### What will happen in your session?
* A discussion on governments using biometric data as identifiers for everything
* A look at Aadhaar in India as a case study
* A conversation on how people can get involved to demand their privacy
* Mapping out the steps to action

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
* Actionable steps participants can take in the Aadhaar campaign
* A map for how to make sure governments don't go down this pathway.



### Time needed
60 mins

title: Finding the Frames in News, Together (NewsFrames Software Demo)
body:
**[ UUID ]** 46e92894-a649-47a9-a145-57e565a375b6

**[ Session Name ]** Finding the Frames in News, Together (NewsFrames Software Demo)
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** connie moon sehat
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Global Voices
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @connieimdialog




### What will happen in your session?
The underlying frames, or agendas, in news can be hard to see.  At Global Voices, we’ve created a journalism platform called NewsFrames (https://newsframes.globalvoices.org) to help make this easier.  It enables people to write stories together on news coverage in ways that incorporates data, analytical methods, and bridge-building perspectives.

Some data that NewsFrames incorporates is from Media Cloud (mediacloud.org) and from an experimental library of algorithms from Georgia Institute of Technology that we’re calling “Bias Detector.”  Our session will show how these tools can enable collaborative writing about frames or agenda setting in news coverage.  

Because NewsFrames is new and still undergoing some development, we also welcome feedback from the participants that can inform its use and future.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
After this session, participants should understand how to write an article that compares different dominant themes in news coverage by different outlets like this one: https://newsframes.globalvoices.org/2017/07/07/what-does-the-media-say-is-happening-in-venezuela/.

In addition, participants will have experience in a new, open software platform that encourages best practices and enables collaboration in news authorship. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will require a computer with internet/wifi connection and projector to demo the software. In addition, if there are not a lot of participants, those attending can bring their laptop/tablet with a connection to participate actively in the session. 



### Time needed
60 mins

title: Youth led internet health fire side chat

milestone.title: Youth Zone
milestone.description:
**Space description**
For our collective sake
Let your passion create a story
Let your passion design the day
Let that passion fight the cause
Let our voice be heard

The Youth Zone is like a poem—creative, unexpected, powerful. Join this space for youth leaders and their mentors who are creating art, technology and positive social change. From a Raspberry Pi-coded singing potato to our fireside chat on Internet health, come explore our collective tomorrow.

body:
**[ UUID ]** dc1f7a4a-ec21-4f99-98ce-cbf94b385d8c

**[ Session Name ]** Youth led internet health fire side chat
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Dorine  Flies



**[ Additional facilitators ]** Shwetal Shah


### What will happen in your session?
Within the Youth Zone we have 27 sessions being led by young people aged 8+ with a total of 33 sessions festival wide. As part of their acceptence into the youth zone we are requesting they take part in the fire side chat on the Youth Internet of health project.

Each participant will be asked to share with us what one of the 5 themes means to them based on:

    Privacy & Security
    Openness
    Decentralization
    Digital Inclusion
    Web Literacy

https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/internet-health

As a pre cursar to this they will have been asked to post their blog on Medium.com to start off their reflection on the above themes; again writing a blog is part and parcel of being accepted into the Youth Zone as this year MozFest is so "Themed". For a youth audience we felt it was best to help them reflect on how their session fits within, intersects and/or address's one or more of the 5 main themes set out in the internet of health report, rather than us tell them.

To achive this we are drawing from a number of sessions who have submitted to MozFest and have been accepted within the Youth Zone to help us set the stage and deliver training on the Friday together with set homework on their "Themed" choice to go research the topic in the themed space. This to fully support our young people being confident in standing up for 5-7 minutes to let us know what the report means to them.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This will be an eddited filmed event, we want our youth to get a taste of what it feels like to be filmed while talking. This while giving them the reasurance that it's ok to "Mess up talking on stage". Public speaking is a daunting task to many and only through the doing can we start to be more confortable with the experience itself. The objectives of this session are 2 fold: (A) Be a gaint sand box for our youth experience public speaking and (B) Record the views of our youth on what Mozilla has set out in their Internet of health report,  youth being the ones who are going to have to pick up the batton to carry on fighting for a free internet for all.

### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Hire of a camera for the weekend

### Time needed
Afternoon slots in room 213 Fri, Sat and Sun.

### What will happen in your session?

Practical Politics: How does Politics really work? We're proposing a sessions based on our discussions with Dorine on how politics truly works. This is an interactive session which gets attendees to take part in their own mock election, then experience how changes are proposed, blocked and made. They will get to practice their public speaking skills, debating and discuss the state of UK democracy in 2017. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to increase their confidence in understanding politics and how it works. As a result, making them more engaged in the democratic process, and more likely to be pro active as citizens in creating the change they wish to see.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, post it notes, flipchart, flipchart board/stand, flipchart pens, blu tack or white tack, coloured A3 paper & pens for participants, felt tips/markets, speakers, wifi/internet access

All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Queering Privacy through Queer Hacking

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

body:
**[ UUID ]** ab23601a-7fa0-46f8-8602-b47e0d0be331

**[ Session Name ]** Queering Privacy through Queer Hacking
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sarah Lewis
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mascherari Press
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @s-rah




### What will happen in your session?
After a brief introduction to the multiple challenges that queer (lgbtq+) people face trying to discover information, find partners and simply exist online there will be a guided group discussion on how we can build & leverage existing technologies to make the connected world more queer friendly.

We will explore topics such as the risks of queer online dating, censorship of LGBT educational content and the harm of real name polices and the group discussion will center around how we subvert & reduce these risks.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
I want participants to go away with a deeper understanding of the challenges of designing systems with queer people in mind. Often well meaning, but naive, solutions to real problems (e.g. harassment) end up also harming queer communities the most and once we understand that not only can be we make the lives of queer people better, but we can also improve the internet for everyone.

I am hoping the group discussion unearths some clever solutions that participants can take forward also.



### Time needed
90 mins

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:

Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. **[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jessica Rose
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** FutureLearn

### What will happen in your session?
This session is designed to give attendees with limited to no experience in mentorship the knowledge, skills and confidence needed to begin mentoring in their technology and open web communities as an individual mentor or through established mentorship programs. Short activities will be used to learn about best practices in onboarding new mentees and working with them to develop goals. Content focusing on how to support mentees through successes and setbacks, the ethical responsibilities of mentorship and sourcing mentee feedback will be addressed during this session. We will also look at how and when a mentor relationship may have to end and how best to sunset the relationship.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This session should provide attendees with the information and confidence to serve as mentors the technology and open web communities either as individuals or as part of an established mentorship program. Attendees should understand their responsibilities and boundaries as mentors. Attendees will know how to determine and rank the goals of their mentees, how to set goals in mentorship and how and when to sunset a relationship with a mentee productively. This should allow attendees without any experience in mentorship to begin acting as mentors and supporting individuals within their communities in an informed fashion.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A projector and some office supplies (paper, pens) for notes would be very helpful for this session.

60 mins

title: Threatened Voices: Activating a Database of Threats Against Digital Activists
body:
**[ UUID ]** 8d40de32-bb5e-47b1-95d3-207730dad60c

**[ Session Name ]** Threatened Voices: Activating a Database of Threats Against Digital Activists
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ellery Biddle
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Global Voices


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Mahsa Alimardani


### What will happen in your session?
We will give a demo of our Threatened Voices database and teach participants how to use our data and visualization tools for research and activism. The database, which will have its soft launch just before MozFest, contains several hundred case files on activists and independent media workers who have been targeted with legal, physical or technical threats due to their work online. Our suite of tools will allow any user to search, analyze and produce simple visualizations of data in the set to support research or activism on free speech issues.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our goal is to introduce the Mozilla community to Threatened Voices and teach new users how they can utilize and benefit from the data in their own work.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Free Basics and Other Cheap Connectivity Innovations: What Works in Local Context?
body:
**[ UUID ]** 06214c2f-d785-44bf-98c4-33223e135b42

**[ Session Name ]** Free Basics and Other Cheap Connectivity Innovations: What Works in Local Context?
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ellery Biddle
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Global Voices


**[ Additional facilitators ]** 


### What will happen in your session?
I'll begin this session with a quick presentation of Global Voices' research on Facebook's Free Basics initiative, wherein we tested their app in six different countries and evaluated against open internet and usability standards, as well as local needs and interests. We'll then use this as a model for brainstorming other decentralized usability and context-focused research projects where savvy tech users around the world can easily contribute experiential research and documentation to inquiries into the local and contextual efficacy of different ICT4D and low-connectivity focused tech innovations.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Build a sustainable model through which tech savvy users can contribute to the growing body of global knowledge about the benefits and drawbacks of different innovations in places where internet access is scarce.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector
Large paper pads
Markers


### Time needed
60 mins

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Marie-sol Glendza
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Hampton court house school


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Marie France Taylor 


### What will happen in your session?
Caesar Cipher wheel is an exiting activity for a small group of people around 5-6 participants for beginners. A story will be created for the participants to make up. One of the participants will be writing an encrypted message using the Caesar Cipher after they have completed the message the other 4-5 people will attempt to decipher it. 

After the participants have mastered the way of using a code or codes they will have to look around the building for coded messages for them to find and the winner will receive a special award. They also have to search twitter for hidden messages to archive the final challenge.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
My goal of the session is to share my knowledge to other people for them to comprehend what cryptography is really about. 
Cryptography is a useful skill to learn because it is used for keeping your personal information safe and without it everything on the internet would be open sourced and people could read your personal information such as your bank details or your email password. Without it nothing on the internet would be kept a secret and this session will give you a further understanding of the science behind it and how it works like clockwork.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
-Paper
-Pen
-Pencil
-Scissor 
-Glue


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Meet Me Half Way: Team Relations & Communications in Open Source Spaces

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

body:

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Victoria O'Dell
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Open Austin
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @VictoriaODell




### What will happen in your session?
As a new designer in open source, I have stumbled around trying to figure out how to work on projects with developers and other team members. Being new to the scene things can be a little scary, especially in spaces that seem very technical. With any team, diversity matter. Producing documentation, recording process, and sharing resources are important in keeping up relations in open source spaces so we can better innovate together. 

Here we will have an open discussion on file management, team communication, design hand-offs, and more. We'll share real team challenges, successes, and solutions. We will come away with a shared doc of our tips, tricks, and resources for working as teams in the open. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
I want people to walk away with clear suggestions on how their teams can better communicate on their projects moving forward and have a list of resources and tools that may aid them. By the end of our time together we should create a shared document with our compiled tips and tricks for team communication and collaboration that has worked in different situations. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We may need stickies and pens that way we can see what ideas are most popular so we can prioritize discussion. 

Attendees should bring their computers to take notes for our shared document. We can also share computers or have designated note takers. 




### Time needed
90 mins

### What will happen in your session?
During the session, participants will have a chance to board a time machine and go back to a time when their lives weren't documented from birth to death.  This time travel trip will give participants a chance to reflect on how different their lives were would have been. Then return to today and split into groups to discuss different subjects handed out by the facilitator. Participants will then be given time to plan their digital legacy.  There will be a debriefed and time to share out with the whole group.  

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
How understanding internet health can help youth, caregivers, and adults protect & plan for their own digital legacy. This session will walk participants through a time in life when everything about their life, from birth to death, wasn't documented by the internet. 

By the end of the session, participants will walk away with a plan to understand, protect and plan their own digital legacy.

title: The Technology for Social Justice Field Scan Exhibition

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

**[ Session Name ]** The Technology for Social Justice Field Scan Exhibition  
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Berhan Taye  Gemeda 
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Open Technology Institute and Research Action Design 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @btayeg

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Georgia Bullen ,Maya Wagoner 


### What will happen in your session?
Our exhibit will share the findings of the Technology for Social Justice field scan research project. The T4SJ research project is a participatory action research co-led by Research Action Design (RAD), Open Technology Institute (OTI) and their nine partner organizations. 
We will have visualizations, practitioners' stories, and interactive displays that will show the results of our one year research documenting, mapping, and analyzing the space many of us hold using technology for social good. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We spent half of 2016 and most of 2017 trying to understand how people that work with technology to advance social good and social justice come into this field. How those that use technology in the public’s interest define the space they work in and how they see the challenges and the threats they face. Our goal is to share these findings and much more with the MozFest Community. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will need a projector, an exhibition area, and easels. 


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: AfroScanned.

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

### What will happen in your session?
In this session, I will provide a background around the history of photogrammetry and colour vision as related to race, computer vision and colour in film. Following this, the participants will be able to 3D scan themselves and we will critique what it feels like to have a second virtual self. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The primary goal of the session is to generate an understanding of how 3D scanning works, the history of digitization and how it documents certain narratives online, as well as critique the process. Ultimately making the connection between computer vision and understanding the importance of diverse online representations in imagery, and in future, digital renditions of humanness in virtual formats.

title: Teaching open data & civic literacy in the streets’ of New York City.

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 7c609c55-cee4-46c7-ab56-93884a3460a9

**[ Session Name ]** Teaching open data & civic literacy in the streets’ of New York City.
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Noel Hidalgo
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** BetaNYC
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @BetaNYC

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Lauren Rennée,Emily Goldman


### What will happen in your session?
Since fighting for the passage of NYC’s open data law, BetaNYC has sought collaborators on how to teach and empower the next generation of civic hackers. In 2014, BetaNYC was commissioned to develop an intro to open data course. It quickly became apparent that every day user environments would limit how the class could be taught. In 2015, BetaNYC started to develop novel approaches to teach within internet limited environments. In this session, we will walk you through our pedagogy and lead you to a road where the internet is limited, the data is limitless, and a card game is your guide. Join us for an hour-long journey to discuss data literacy, algorithms, civic architecture, and algorithms.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will walk out of the session with a “mad libs” / “Cards Against Humanity” deck of cards and a new approach as how to teach civic / municipal data in an internet / computer constrained environment. Additionally, they will learn how to use municipal data as a tool for education, empowerment, and self-determination. This session will briefly talk about identifying community partners, teachable key data values, and how to build a deck of physical cards that enable the student to narrate and discuss data in a no-internet environment. At the end, we hope to gather feedback to improve the card game and discuss a shared space to share insights across the smart cities digital/literacy divide.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
While we can host this conversation without a projector, we desire a projector and electrical outlets.


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 0701c199-7ab8-45f0-9c14-108d818d8f56

**[ Session Name ]** Defining, Combating, and Designing Against Online Harassment
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Kaitlin Mahar
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Haystack Group at MIT CSAIL
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @kmahar

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Amy Zhang


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will split into small groups (3-4) for duration of session.
First they will discuss what defines online harassment, and whether certain things constitute it. 
Next, we’ll present a few different examples of online harassment on different platforms, and ask them to discuss whether the example is harassment. We'll then share what the actual platform decided. 
Then they'll brainstorm ways they can support friends (or anyone) on the internet that they see experiencing harassment. 
Finally, each group will choose a platform and brainstorm ways to work with, or around it, to prevent harassment (our tool Squadbox is one example of this.)
In the end we'll ask each group to briefly present important points from their conversation, and add our own thoughts.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is twofold. 
First, to give participants a better understanding of online harassment in general: how it manifests itself on various platforms, how there is no consensus on what exactly it is, and the impacts it can have on individuals and online communities. 
Secondly, to empower participants to take action. They will learn how they can help people experiencing it in non-technical ways, as well as how interface and system design, and platform policies, can have an impact on whether, and how, users experience harassment. We aim to give them the tools they need to think critically about how to combat and prevent harassment through better design and innovative solutions that work around or with existing platforms. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, paper, pens


### Time needed
60 mins

### What will happen in your session?
In this session, I will present how performing artists can easily and cheaply learn digital skills such as web design and digital marketing in order to better market themselves and their work. Based on my own personal experience of going from a chinese opera singer to engineer in a year, attendees will learn to quickly create their own portfolio website, as well as all the digital tools they need to succeed as a modern artist and how to continue learning online for free. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Besides demonstrating a basic curriculum arts educators could be incorporating to better serve and prepare artists for the 21st century, this session will also highlight how the booming tech industry today is in dire need of creative thinkers and artists and how by utilizing digital education tools such Mozilla Thimble, A-Frame, and Udacity, performing artists can grow not only professionally, but creatively.

**[ UUID ]** 10c00892-84a8-428a-a70f-dfed59ea54af

**[ Session Name ]** Creating Integrated Histories by Building Digital Timelines
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Carlos Pareja
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Global Action Project
**[ Submitter's Github ]** n/a

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Youth Facilitator 1,Youth Facilitator 2,


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will engage in a hands-on digital production workshop utilizing Global Action Project’s Media History Timeline to build a dynamic, portfolio-style presentation of online stories that visually position participants' lived experiences and larger social and political events chronologically. Stories are also positioned as layers to show the intersectionality of stories, how eras can be defined, and how struggles move through cycles. Many of us live the stories of our movements’ histories, but lack tools to see how our stories intersect with histories of struggle. In this political climate, it's crucial to place our stories in historical context and challenge dominant narratives. In our workshop, participants can share stories and find connections between our diverse peoples' histories.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our goal is to provide participants with a digital tool to build a dynamic, timeline of online stories that demonstrate the power of diverse stories on an open Internet. As partisan battles shift communications policy with attempts to dismantle a neutral Internet, an online tool that aggregates personal stories and alternative histories is a crucial representation of the heterogeneity of the web. It is our hope that building these digital timelines will deepen the analysis of how stories we see and create are linked to history. We will see how the backdrop of history can be used to present a broader, more embracing perspective of our connected communities through stories we share and explore online.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Laptops connected to the Internet for attendees who do not have an online device would be helpful. However, smartphones and tablets can be used for this workshop, although the interface may be a bit tight on a small screen.


### Time needed
60 mins
