**[ Submitter's Name ]** Amy Mather

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @MiniGirlGeek




### What will happen in your session?
I have made a photobooth previously for Manchester Science Festival. This takes a photo, processes the photo by taking each pixel colour value and drawing RGB squares from it, and then prints out the photo. The booth is placed in front of a stool - the stool we used at the science festival broke so I think we will need to source another one. The booth is controlled by a foot pedal, photos can be retaken as many times as required before printing. I have it set up so its easy to change the theme of the UI so I can make a mozfest themed one.

Photos here:
https://twitter.com/MiniGirlGeek/status/784079594861293568

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Teach people that you can make lots of colours using just red green and blue light and that this is how screens work. They will be able to take home a photo of themselves with each pixel decomposed.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I have all the electrical equipment required, although paper and ink will be required. Additionally I cannot transport the photo booth myself - it's quite heavy and bulky.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. **[ UUID ]** b32dc150-6d09-406c-803f-02fc94b4d9d9

**[ Session Name ]** Wring your Fibre
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Neharika Mahajan



**[ Additional facilitators ]** Ashita,


### What will happen in your session?
During the session, emerging eco-friendly fibres such as bamboo, hemp and banana fibres will be used by the participants to weave small tokens such as coasters, table mats etc. They will:
- wring the fibre to make their own yarn 
- design the product on an interface
- weave their designs using yarn on hand-held mini looms

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The session aims to raise awareness on these new fibres and their potential in existing industries such as textile and paper. Given the stress placed on cotton farmers in developing countries, development of these new fibres will help distribute demand over a larger group of farmers and thus create income for many more farmers. In textiles, these new fibres can also empower artisans who work on handlooms to create newer products that meet the needs of our world and its needs for environment friendly options. The overall objective is to introduce participants to innovative models being created at the grassroots, which are based onc rcular economy.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will need a projector, screen, power cord and stationery supplies such as drawing sheets, sketch pens and post-its.


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** a83e818b-1a5a-4628-a4a4-4f690126ec84

**[ Session Name ]** Decentralization and Dignity against Digital Colonialism
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Renata Avila
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** World Wide Web Foundation


**[ Additional facilitators ]** @pazpena,


### What will happen in your session?
Our talk will aim to discuss "Digital Colonialism" and how autonomous, decentralised solutions could bring freedom and dignity. Today, tech companies are in a quest of global domination, penetrating every government, computing every citizen movement, mediating every act of any connected person’s life. Beyond privacy and security, the alarming tension whose emergence we are witnessing is the one between control and freedom, not only of the individual, but of entire populations and regions. Some criticise it as a form of “digital colonialism”, others defend it as progress, indicating that those companies provide better services than corrupt governments. The debate is heating up and we want to have a smart conversation about it. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Start a discussion on whether  and connect the sociological and political importance of free software, decentralised technologies, ethical frames for data, web literacy and autonomous, decentralised solutions to tackle colonial efforts, resulting in freedom and dignity for people. Discuss whether "digital colonialism" is a good term to describe the current phenomenon of power concentration and growth strategies of technology companies. 



### Time needed
60 mins

title: Data in politics: why privacy matters for free and fair elections?

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 91e95118-0ca4-451d-b09c-2cba8c30301a

**[ Session Name ]** Data in politics: why privacy matters for free and fair elections? 
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Renata  Avila 
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** World Wide Web Foundation


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Claudio Agosti @_vecna,


### What will happen in your session?
Recent political campaigns and processes around the World show that there has been a sharp rise in the use of online spaces as part of electoral and political debate. How can we ensure this transition strengthens freedom of expression and free and fair elections in the South, where elections are still fragile? And, how can digital tools help nurture rather than undermine electoral processes?  How relevant is privacy and literacy when you are participating in elections?  Our session will discuss a mix of soft and hard regulations for online political advertising, and complimentary online privacy protections for voters with concrete examples of recent political processes and emerging regulation North and South. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our attendees will understand better the emerging challenges and opportunities that the Internet offers during elections. We will have a conversation around three different concerns: (1) the impact of politically-targeted advertising and its vendors; (2) The digital gap of those lacking the literacy to follow electoral campaigns online; and (3) why data privacy matters for voters? 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We do not need. We will bring a box with "old school, vintage electoral posters and postcards to remind us how far are those days... Attendees can collect them and bring them home after the session. 


### Time needed
less than 60 mins

title: You Can Triage! How to pitch in to help open source projects.

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

### What will happen in your session?
Bug triage is a critical part of open source projects. In this session, I'll teach participants about triaging bugs in open source projects in general and Firefox in particular. Participants will learn what makes a good bug, and how and when to take steps to improve a bug's  quality, and what to do to get a bug in shape for a project maintainer to decide what to do with the bug.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Someone with basic web literacy will be able to triage non-complex bugs in the Firefox project, and know what steps to take with more complicated bugs. They should also be able search Bugzilla for bugs which need triage and be able to edit them.

I'll provide my own laptop, but will require a project.

90 mins

title: Scratch based HTML Explorer

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

### What will happen in your session?
HTML Explorer

Designed as a tool to help Scratchers understand HTML this session uses a Scratch project to allow participants to explore html code through the Scratch interface seeing in real time the changes they make to their code.

This session will be co-created and led by Alex Venezia a year 6 pupil from the Primary School where I teach in Walhamstow. I have spoken with Emrys Green from Arts Award and he has suggested this should come under Web Literacy but as part of the youth led strand.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This session will be an introduction to both Scratch and HTML. Those new to Scratch will discover a new and highly accessible gateway to learning code. Those new to HTML will discover an easy to use HTML simulator that will allow them to experiment >> understand >> produce code that can be copied and pasted to create a real html webpage by the end of the session.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Our session requires 15 laptops (should be able to cover ourselves)
Electricity
Projector
Small sound system
Tables, chairs
Internet access


### Time needed
60 mins

**[ UUID ]** 63f67568-f6c2-41de-bfd2-475b174ca6a0

**[ Session Name ]** Demystifying ethereum to build your own decentralized app (Ðapp) using blockchain 
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Abhiram Ravikumar
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Tech Speakers
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @abhi12ravi




### What will happen in your session?
The session will start with an overview of blockchain technology, move on to what a distributed ledger is, then introduce a real life example of bitcoin - its evolution, application and future. 

Once participants realize the extent and use of blockchains, I will then introduce the concept of decentralized apps and the ethereum platform. After the context is set, we’ll dive into the hands-on workshop (https://goo.gl/5GgEg3).

- Setup development environment - Install testrpc, web3js and start test blockchain
- Smart contracts: Use solidity (an objected-oriented programming language) to write out a simple contract that increments votes and returns the count of votes
- Setup a simple website to invoke the contract methods
- Play with the application and see blockchain in live

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The aim of the workshop is to ensure that participants are aware of the entire ethereum stack and by themselves - able to compile, deploy and interact with the application. Participants are made aware about blockchain - a decentralized database that is used to make sure that transactions are immutable and helps build trust among its users. At the end of the workshop, the participants would’ve built their first decentralized voting application using the ethereum framework on the blockchain. 

The larger goal is to help participants to appreciate decentralization as a philosophy and  the concept of trust over the internet to build applications on their own or contribute to the plethora of open source Ðapps listed here (https://dapps.ethercasts.com/).


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We would need a few sheets of paper and pens to put down Ethereum's architecture on paper. This would help participants understand the concepts better.


### Time needed
90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 52159c21-e6bd-4d3e-aed3-e438dbd3c558

**[ Session Name ]** Data Selfie (Installation)
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Hang Do Thi Duc

**[ Submitter's Github ]** 01fade




### What will happen in your session?
Data Selfie is a browser extension that helps users track themselves on Facebook; when they click, type, scroll, dwell. It then predicts various personality traits based on that data.

This installation presents one user’s results as a time-based data visualization. The projection on translucent material addresses on one hand the ‘glassy’ consumer and the transparent person, but also on the other hand the lack of information transparency.

Visual examples: http://dataselfie.it/installation

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Internet users create different identities on the different platforms. They control how they want to be seen. Data Selfie addresses the data profiles created about them by machines at Facebook, Google and Co. – the only profiles they never get to see, but unconsciously create.
This project aims to provide a personal perspective on data mining, predictive analytics and our online data identity – including inferred information from our consumption. In our data society algorithms are omnipresent and seemingly omniscient.
One thing is certain, Big Data algorithms increasingly define our lives. Therefore, it is important – especially for those who are indifferent to this issue – to be aware of the power and influence of our data on ourselves. 
 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A technical diagram can be found at http://dataselfie.it/installation. If space is not sufficient there might be an alternative setup that requires less.

Since this is a projection a darkened area would be best.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: We're All Connected: Bridging the Digital Divide Through A Rural/Urban Youth Collaborative

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Steve Goodman
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Educational Video Center


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Gabriel


### What will happen in your session?
Youth from rural Appalachian East Tennessee and from low income neighborhoods in New York City will share experiences facing inequitable access to broadband in their communities. Through this experiential session, they will engage participants in their collaborative digital video and web project.  Participants will view and respond to clips from their documentary and explore their collaborative websites-in-progress.  They will explore the problem through the youth presenters' perspectives and see the advocacy efforts in both rural and urban regions that are addressing different but related challenges through education, training, and cooperative ownership of facilities.   

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To build awareness of the distinct challenges with broadband access that youth and their families in rural communities face and those also faced by youth in low income, particularly new immigrant urban  communities. They will also share the advocacy efforts taking place and the unique model of their project's urban/rural collaboration, made possible with generous support from the Mozilla Hive NYC Innovation Fund.  



### Time needed
60 mins

**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization

**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Article 19
**[ Submitter's Github ]** paulinabustos

### What will happen in your session?
We will work with the participants on conducting a focal  Open Data evaluation in their country. The idea is to base this exercise, on the work that other people have done in their countries. In particular, we will use the methodology used by Artigo 19 in Brazil. For the session, the participants will: 
- Choose a topic that it is important for their work: Violence, Crime, Women’s Rights, are topics that will be encouraged. 
- Go to their country’s Data
- Rate data based on  Technical and Thematic indicators 
- Research International indicators 
- Produce a one-pager of the evaluation of data on that topic 
- Publish one-pager and put it available for the government and thematic institutions 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Two main physical outcomes: 
- A focal assessment on Open Data that will help on demanding more and better Open Data 
- Assistants have the opportunity to focalized and utilized a Community driven Open Data methodology, instead of a broad method. 

Promote better ways to demand and create Data. In the last couple of years, we have been occupied with creating a Data Pipeline, this Data Pipeline is technical and structural. It is a sorrow to admit that our efforts have been at best insufficient for the Open Data social demands. Therefore we need better methods, our attempt with this session is create the new iteration of Open Data demands. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Post-its, dashboard and projector. 




### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 49460b3e-5b64-4c29-af2f-ec2f9823bf9a

**[ Session Name ]** A View from the Outside: Internet Access and Usage by People Experiencing Homelessness in the U.S.
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Beth Vann-Turnbull
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Housing Families First


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Scott Turnbull


### What will happen in your session?
Approximately 550,000 men, women, and children are homeless in the United States on any given night. A variety of resources to help people experiencing homelessness are available online, ranging from searchable databases of services to applications for financial assistance. How do individuals who are homeless access the internet? What devices and tools are most helpful?

Session participants will interactively learn how people in homelessness access the internet and which free, sometimes surprising, online tools are useful in connecting them to housing and the broader community. Participants also will have an opportunity to experience accessing commonly-needed services on various internet-enabled devices within the time limitations sometimes imposed on usage for those living in homelessness.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to help participants realize what simple, real-world digital solutions make a difference in the lives of people who are homelessness, based on my 14 years experiencing in working with homeless families. Session participants will walk away with an increased understanding of digital challenges faced by people experiencing homelessness and fresh ideas on how common online apps and social media platforms can effectively be used by people experiencing homelessness. 

Throughout this interactive session, participants will have the opportunity to try their hand at searching and applying for housing resources under time constraints and to share their suggestions of yet unexplored online apps and tools that may be beneficial to people living on the street or in homeless shelters.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A projector to share slides and a white board or flip chart are needed. Attendees with tablets, smartphones, and laptops will be asked to use them for the interactive exercises incorporated into the session.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 4a532f59-574a-41fb-bde0-9da7f4ae2a0f

**[ Session Name ]** Keeping Safe Spaces Safe and Secure
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Allison Ivey
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Learn All the Time Network
**[ Submitter's Github ]** https://github.com/billfitzgerald/

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Bill Fitzgerald,Robert Friedman


### What will happen in your session?
This session explores the challenges facing organizations as the demand for more data leads to a need for sound data security policies.  Although universally applicable, we will examine privacy and security through the lens of organizations that provide educational and safe spaces to youth.

Leveraging MozFest participant’s global perspective and expertise we examine these questions:
a.) How do privacy and security concerns vary across a global community?
b.) What current risks keep organizational leaders up at night?
c.) What resources and training would benefit these organizations?
d.) What should training include to be relevant?

The session incorporates interactive scenarios and connects them to specific practices that improve privacy and security by focusing on practical human-centered steps organizations can implement.



### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of this session is to:
•	foster a dialogue and gather expertise from the global community about the current resources and best practices for privacy and security;
•	uncover insights on international issues and universal concerns for privacy and security;
•	crowd-source content and approaches to help in the development of a privacy and security training program for organizational leaders;
•	document barriers and issues that need to be addressed to improve practice; and
•	define clear next steps for implementation and monitoring of privacy and security in order to improve compliance and best practice.

The outcomes of these discussions and the training materials will be shared so that all participants can benefit from the collective brainpower in the session.




### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Our session will require chart paper (if available), markers, post-it notes and colored dot stickers (for real time voting and prioritization of ideas).

We will bring any handouts or other resources that are not accessible via the etherpad.

Because one of the goals of this session is to emphasize that privacy and security concerns are best addressed via both technical and non-technical means, we are intentionally emphasizing both low-tech and more explicitly technical approaches that make an impact on improving privacy and security practice regardless of organizational resources or budgets.




### Time needed
90 mins

Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

**[ UUID ]** 2f751e38-73cc-4241-be93-3a02cd9c9011

**[ Session Name ]** Worldbuilding for Safe, Secure, and Private Futures: Producing Internet-Related Roleplaying Games and Interactive Fiction 
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Antero Garcia
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Stanford University
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @anterobot

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Chris Proctor


### What will happen in your session?
In this hands-on workshop, participants will first identify issues of privacy and security that they can innovatively explore and convey through gaming and narrative contexts. By defining the key ideas, feelings, and actions that these issues embody, participants will then explore possibilities for collaborative storytelling through tabletop gaming tools like remixable gaming systems and through producing digital interactive fiction. Participants will then work to produce a set of games and narratives about exploring, experiencing, and playing concepts of privacy and security. By the end of this session, attendees will have a self-created product, a deeper understanding of internet health, and a set of ludic practices to engage in play and production for future teaching, publication, and dialogue. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
At the end of this session, participants will have played through role-playing narratives that illustrate how to embody internet health practices. Further, they will have authored their own stories—either collectively through designing and play-testing a role-playing game or individually through writing an interactive fiction narrative. These texts will be shared both with other participants in the session and online for the general public. All materials created will be available for others to read, remix, and share after the session ends. By discussing, playing, and producing games and interactive texts, participants will develop key habits and routines related to internet safety and ways to share these practices with other audiences. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
n/a

90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 01d3de01-7c08-4e36-be86-fc5ee9acd7ac

**[ Session Name ]** Anonymous Whistleblowing with SecureDrop
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jennifer Helsby
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Freedom of the Press Foundation
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @redshiftzero




### What will happen in your session?
This session will describe the importance of anonymous whistleblowing in today's political climate. In this session, we will introduce participants to SecureDrop, a free and open source whistleblowing platform, and describe how it addresses the critical need for a way for journalists and sources to communicate securely and anonymously. Many large news organizations including the Associated Press (AP), the Guardian,  the Washington Post and the New York Times are all now running SecureDrop in their newsrooms to preserve an anonymous tip line in the presence of increasing surveillance powers by governments and corporations. We will describe how SecureDrop works, how you can install it, and how you can contribute to the project. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of the session is to provide an introduction to a critical project in today's political climate. Participants can become contributors if they are interested, learn more about how to install the project, or just learn more about a challenging political and technical problem. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector

60 mins

**[ UUID ]** b45ac696-8667-4084-af34-1fc6291c8c69

**[ Session Name ]** Just Numbers
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Nasser Eledroos
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** ACLU, Media Mobilizing Project, Article19, Demand Progress, Media Democracy Fund
**[ Submitter's Github ]** eledroos

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Di Luong,Pierce Stanley,Paulina Bustos Arellano,Benjamin Dean


### What will happen in your session?
Machine learning and face recognition software are being increasingly used by police and law enforcement in the US for surveillance and censorship of political rally participants, civil liberty advocates, and citizens. This is an introduction to how police collect data from citizens through surveillance equipment. Session will discuss how to analyze open records and surveillance data.

Participants will discuss real case studies, like recent case of ACLU obtaining social media data collected by police to track activists online.  Participants will work in small groups to develop a community solution to current surveillance tactics. Workshop is intended for both non-technical and technical solutions for fixing bias data collected from predictive policing practices. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will learn how to use dataset as a storytelling tool. We want to transform spreadsheets and police records into human stories. Law enforcement agencies are using flawed data as the basis for their algorithmic equations, calculations that are determining who gets arrested or go to prison in America. 

Our session will provide participants with 1) increase understanding of surveillance technology is used within neighborhoods across the United States and online, 2) examples of community efforts to combat invasive law enforcement tactics through legislation and advocacy, and 3) tools for documenting and organizing against surveillance and predictive policing practices that encroach our civil liberties, human rights, and Internet privacy. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, Markerboard/markers.


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Teaching the Web with Games

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Gideon Thomas

### What will happen in your session?
This session brings together teachers, students, and anyone who likes or is interested in teaching and/or learning about the web and coding to figure out what works well when you try to teach web technologies in a fun and interactive way. We explore the pros and cons about integrating a game into a tutorial about HTML/CSS/JavaScript (the three basic web languages). We will explore some examples along with personal experiences about teaching using games (for e.g. I created a ["get you feet wet with JavaScript" tutorial with Pacman](https://thimbleprojects.org/gideonthomas/202506/) for a group of students entering their first year for a degree in computer studies) and what appeals to different age groups.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Attendees learn from each other's experiences and perspectives about teaching web technologies using games and will hopefully incorporate that when creating curriculum.

For the presenter:
- A projector
- A whiteboard

For the attendees:
- Post-its
- Pens/markers

60 mins

**[ UUID ]** 660dc3a0-1a9d-4e98-9209-0df83ed24b56

**[ Session Name ]** Hijacking the medium of public space
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Wael Eskandar

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @weskandar




### What will happen in your session?
I will present past experiences in Egypt where public space was completely open to do anything and we chose to move media and information to the street as a public medium capable of transmitting information collected by citizens and other outlets inaccessible to the public. I will ask participants to contribute as to what else can be brought to the public and how. We shall traverse obstacles of reclaiming public space and discuss new ways of utilizing it other than protests and graffiti. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The session will attempt to understand the importance of utilizing public space and why it seems to be so carefully guarded by the state. Conventional methods such as television and radio operate either under rules of censorship or rules of profit making and corporate and political interests. It is important to find new ways of bypassing this sort of bias. But just like the Egyptian experience of bringing information out to the open using public space as a medium, perhaps more can be delivered such as skills and tools as well as a different perspective, particularly to people whose physical spaces deter them for accessing the virtual spaces we all do on the internet.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
- Speakers

90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 6b8f65da-599a-4282-b8db-67e6b8d699e8

**[ Session Name ]** Wikipedia Games
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Anne-Marie Scott
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Edinburgh
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @ammienoot




### What will happen in your session?
Participants will be (gently) introduced to Wikipedia through a series of short fun games / activities.

(1) Wikirace challenges players to get from one article to another in the shortest time using only links within pages. How fast can you get from Trump to Armageddon?

(2) Citation Hunt helps to find and fix missing citations on Wikipedia. How many can you do in 10 minutes?

(3) Histropedia builds interactive timelines from Wikipedia categories. Categorise articles in Wikipedia to improve the timeline.

(4) Wikipedia Text Adventure is an old school style text based adventure game. The inclusion of places in the game relies on geographical coordinates being included on Wikipedia articles. Can you add new locations to the game?

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
After this session participants will have increased familiarity with the content and style of Wikipedia articles and understand concepts of notability and verifiability and how to make small edits to existing pages such as improving citations, adding geographical data and adding categories.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I will provide my own laptop so a data projector or large LCD screen is all that is required.

60 mins

title: Community Building through Technical Documentation

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

### What will happen in your session?
This session will be an interactive workshop that goes over how to create iterative, inclusive, and accessible documentation for technical projects. We’ll look at examples of community-driven documentation, go over how to keep documentation central to development projects, and consider how communities can be built around documentation that allows access to users from diverse backgrounds. This session will result in guidelines for inclusive technical documentation projects.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of the session is to collaboratively, as a group, develop a set of guidelines for inclusive documentation for technical projects. These guidelines will provide best practices and resources for writing documentation that is easy to understand for as many people as possible, building communities around documentation, and driving greater digital inclusivity and accessibility. These goals can continue to expand online following the in-person session at MozFest 2017.

**[ UUID ]** eb18e762-2149-4ce6-a8ea-2f015f09de24

**[ Session Name ]** Algorithmically Mediated Online Information Access (AMOIA)
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ansgar Koene
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Nottingham, Horizon Digital Economy Research institute


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Liz Dowthwaite,Helena Webb,Menisha Patel,Virginia Portillo


### What will happen in your session?
This session will be an interactive audience discussion.
We will start with a mini-experiment, presenting participants with a ‘limited resources’ scenario (e.g. allocation of game character type in an online multi-player game where each type can only be played by one player) and asking them which of five algorithms for assigning game characters to players is most fair. First, under black-box conditions where only algorithm decision information is known. Second when information about the decision criteria of each algorithm are given. 
We will then proceed to discuss a number of case studies related with.
-	The role of recommender algorithms in hoaxes and fake news on the Web
-	Unintended algorithmic discrimination on the web – routes towards detection and prevention

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This session is part of the public engagement work for the UnBias project (http://unbias.wp.horizon.ac.uk) aimed at developing design-, regulation- and education- recommendations to minimize unjustified and inappropriate bias in algorithmic services. It will build on our previous experience of running workshops with youths (12-17 years old), with our stakeholders group of industry, civil-society, regulators, academics and teachers, and at academic conferences.
The goal of the session is to gain insights into the knowledge, perceptions and concerns of people regarding algorithms that intermediate between internet users and online information. These will contribute to the development of our algorithm awareness, empowerment and empathy tool-kits, our submissions to parliamentary inquiries and our work on the IEEE P7003 Standard for Algorithm Bias Considerations.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Overhead projector could be useful, but is not essential.


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 5b2e1a04-bd9c-4952-b189-7c5ea259bb0d

**[ Session Name ]** Trading personal data online
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Jasmin Mahmoodi

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @idigitalized




### What will happen in your session?
In my session, attendees play a short game (‘Public Good’ game). Usually, people start off with an amount of money. In my game, however, people enter the game with no money, but their digital footprints (e.g., age, favourite movies, brands/products bought, location, and similar data commonly revealed online).

Attendees decide whether to share these data (e.g., age, location,…) with a company that uses it to improve their services/products used by millions of people. The company doesn’t only offer an improved service, but also makes more profit, which is paid out to shareholders. Is the improvement of the service enough to trade their data? Or are they only willing to trade data for a monetary return? And if so, how much money?

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
First, my session will be a fun, little game to play that makes attendees think about a dilemma: share my data for a social good (i.e., improved online service)/for a monetary return, or not? Second, it will sensitise attendees to think about their digital footprints as an economic commodity: The quantities of data we produce (e.g., on social media, search engine, online shopping,…) are valuable for many companies that make huge profits from these data. After the game, I will give attendees feedback, so they see how their decisions in the game differed from the average. Furthermore, I will provide information on how to protect data online and attendees have space to talk about this experience with others and me.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
The session doesn’t require many additional materials. To ensure that everyone can attend the session, I would appreciate at least 1-2 laptops/tablets with working Internet connection. Additionally, a board and pens to write on it would be ideal, but not urgently necessary.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ UUID ]** 5a8f74d0-6dfe-4017-bd59-d4667b8bac28

**[ Session Name ]** Host your data on the peer to peer web with Dat
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Danielle  Robinson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Science / Code for Science & Society
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @daniellecrobinson

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Bruno Vieira,Max Ogden


### What will happen in your session?
We will lead a beginner friendly tutorial on hosting a simple website from a personal computer and making it available over the peer to peer web using Dat. Participants will build a basic website and install Dat software on their machine in order to host it. They will then have another participant load their page and store it offline, demonstrating Dat’s P2P nature.

For advanced users, participants will learn how to access and import scientific datasets using the Dat protocol. As the main example, session leader Bruno Vieira will use his expertise as a bioinformaticist to use Dat to load datasets into analysis using Bionode, which can be easily installed on participants computers using Node.js.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our goals are to create a fun and welcoming environment for people at all levels to have fun with decentralized technology. More advanced users can explore the potential of Dat in their workflow, while people who are new to the technology can develop a better understanding of how Dat works through hands-on learning. Further goals of the session are to expose participants to open data sets, as well as introduce concepts like reproducibility and transparency, and to give them the tools to publish their own data online.




### Time needed
60 mins

**[ Session Name ]** Machina a machina: An introduction to APIs through Google Sheets
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Martin Hawksey
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Independent 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @mhawksey

**[ Additional facilitators ]** TBC


### What will happen in your session?
In this workshop participants will have an opportunity to learn about Application Programming Interfaces (APIs). An API is essentially an interface that can be used to retrieve or interact with another application. Many popular online services offer such interfaces, for example Twitter, Flickr and many open source tools like WordPress. Using Google Sheets participants will have a opportunity to learn how to access and use APIs from a relative familiarity of a spreadsheet. Starting by using Google Sheets built-in formula participants will learn how to import and query data. From there more advance techniques will be introduced including writing API calls. 

Modified from http://www.meanboyfriend.com/overdue_ideas/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/4-APIs-CC-BY.pdf CC-BY Owen Stephens  

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of this session is for participants to see the usefulness and the empowerment of APIs, gaining practical skills in API wrangling which they can build upon in their own projects. As well as the opportunities of APIs this session will hopefully also highlight privacy and security issues such as the availability of data from services like Twitter. See how much data is easily accessible from APIs will hopefully allow participants to make more informed decisions about the type of information they share.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I’ll be bringing my own laptop so a data projector is all that is needed. As this workshop is based on using Google Sheets participants should be advised that to fully participate they should bring their own laptop and if not already create a Google account. For participants without laptops or unwilling to create a Google account they will be able to follow progress from what is displayed via the data projector or if other participants with laptops are happy by pairing up.

60 mins

title: Smart Tech Growth: social responsibility in transitioning tech economies
body:
**[ UUID ]** 1b88a3f6-da74-47db-8712-38a7295ccffd

**[ Session Name ]** Smart Tech Growth: social responsibility in transitioning tech economies
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Craig Wiroll
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Foundation
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @Wiroll

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Mark Davis?


### What will happen in your session?
Using the lens of "smart growth" for cities from a planning perspective, what are the responsibilities of the curators of the technology in the development of a changing community?

We will discuss what it means for a community to adapt from a non-tech economy and the outlying variables to consider such as:

- Broadband access to rural & inner-city areas and the result of digital divide
- The responsibility of social-good internally from the tech industry and what the development of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) guidelines looks like
- Gentrification - is it inevitable? Must it always result in negative consequences?

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To get people thinking about how their organizations fit into their local communities.

To create actionable steps to assessing how the tech industry affects the greater overall economy and contributes to negative access to resources - and how to replenish the community resources that are exhausted by high-wage tech careers.

To establish community-specific Corporate Social Responsibility guidelines - and be able to create a cooperative community mindset around those guidelines.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
An easel or somewhere to hang a poster. Post-it (brand name) notes so that the MozFest community and contribute ideas in an analog way.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

**[ UUID ]** 13b49136-e5ea-49c2-ae79-e8cf58d8a7e0

**[ Session Name ]** Create your own off-grid, long-range mobile mesh networks
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Daniela Perdomo
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** goTenna


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Rahul Subramany


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will learn about the potential of truly decentralized connectivity. We'll start with a quick crash-course on the history, political economy, and technology behind telecommunications at-large. Armed with this background, we'll segue into the blue-sky possibilities of creating your own connectivity (rather than plugging into it!) with mobile ad hoc networking protocols. We’ll dive into goTenna Mesh, the first and only way to create your own long-range, off-grid, mobile mesh network anywhere in the world, and attendees will be introduced to the brand-new goTenna Mesh open SDK which turns this new technology into an open platform. We will end with a hands-on workshop related to mobile mesh networks and decentralized bottom-up applications that can be built with the Mesh SDK.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
+ Educate attendees about the need for and the technology that powers community/people-powered mobile mesh networks
+ Provide access to the tools (hardware & software) necessary for attendees to build their own their own off-grid communications projects
+ Inspire attendees to create unique applications in the decentralized connectivity space, using the goTenna Mesh SDK and/or other decentralized protocols and platforms
+ Create a community of like-minded developers who care about building a scalable decentralized connectivity layer that may be essential to increasing scale, resiliency & access to essential connectivity


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Since this session would involve not just people's own personal devices but also goTenna Mesh hardware (and potentially some other RF equipment we would bring), we'd just want to make sure we have counter space for people to spread out and work. Power outlets nearby would also be ideal!


### Time needed
90 mins

title: This Wifi Will Track You

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 0bcba013-02f7-431a-86b8-4f24db21d0fe

**[ Session Name ]** This Wifi Will Track You
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Tiago Fassoni

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @tiagofassoni

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Hsien Ming Wu


### What will happen in your session?
The idea is to leave an open wireless network with the neat title "this wifi will track you".

Upon connecting to the network, the person will be greeted by a login page (at the address "what.is.my.data") explaining that's an experiment to show how trackable are people's online identities and how vulnerable are their devices. 

There will be another website, "all.the.peoples.data", with some aggregate statistics. 

All user data will be deleted at the end of the experiment, all software used will be open source.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
It is really hard to explain to people what is digital security and why it matters. We explain abstract stuff, tracking "in the cloud", evil advertisement bots with malicious code embedded straight from science fiction and, everyday, a new utter flaw in computer systems.

So, in order to tell people why it matters, we are making a wifi network that actively tries to scan the user, to get her information and show how easy it is to get her data.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
It would be nice if mozilla could give us some ubiquity APs for mesh networking (or something like that), but that is not strictly necessary.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Intro to webExtension: Let's build webExtension

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 8313245f-a710-4547-9375-7c63702c109b

**[ Session Name ]** Cut, Copy & Paste: Use (analog!) open source collaboration to make your own MozFest Zine
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sam Muirhead

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @cameralibre

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Judith Carnaby


### What will happen in your session?
Visitors can create a story, drawing, comic or collage about their experience of MozFest. 

They stamp their name and a 'commit number' on their work, make a photocopy, and file the original on a shelf labelled ‘repository’.

The copy is displayed alongside many more works: where others are encouraged to remix, translate or build upon them, allowing stories to evolve with different contexts or voices. 

Copy. Cut. Paste. Draw. Copy. Participants are invited to help on specific tasks via a noticeboard.

Participants can draw from an existing library of public domain images - plus the growing pool of MozFest contributions - to create their own individual zines, enabling a diverse expression of experiences and perspectives at MozFest.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?

- To give people a tangible experience of working creatively in an open source way, without needing to install software, open a terminal, learn git commands, or even use the internet.

- To make & publish zines, expressing the diversity of experiences at MozFest! (conversations visitors had, projects they discovered, awkward moments, fails/wins, new friends and ideas...) 

- Drop-in participants can very quickly tell their story via text or image, fulfil an open task on the 'help needed' board, browse and remix the work of others, and get to know how open source works. More sustained participation can result in their own individual MozFest zine: their own input combined with their favourite contributions, images and ideas from other people.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.

My proposed session requires a lot of different materials, and I can take care of bringing, borrowing or renting the various bits and pieces I need, but any help in finding the following would be appreciated:

- photocopier 

- paper guillotine

- extra typewriter(s)


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

body:
**[ UUID ]** e946d0ea-d34d-4fb6-96a5-2d08d24740c2

**[ Session Name ]** User-centred consent
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Harry Trimble
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** IF
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @projectsbyif

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Sarah Gold,Matthew Sheret,Georgina Bourke,Francesca Alice Guidali


### What will happen in your session?
Data, privacy and permissions need to be taken as seriously as accessibility and usability. Digital rights are becoming a mainstream issue. The next generation of products will be trusted with more data and make more decisions on people’s behalf. To deal with those changes, people making services need common design patterns, shared language, and a community to help them make ethical decisions. 
In this workshop participants will have 90 minutes to sketch better ways for people to share and protect their data, supported by members of the IF team. We’ll use the results to update the open-source Data Permissions Catalogue (catalogue.projectsbyif.com), a repository of approaches to consent that help product teams think differently about the things they make.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want to expand the community contributing to the open-source Data Permissions Catalogue. In addition, and because so much of the work around privacy and security is technical or compliance-driven, we also want to engage with people who are familiar with the issues but might not have a background in thinking about it as a design problem.
The goal is also to think about users: what needs and considerations aren’t present in the catalogue? How can we evolve our thinking in the area, and connect with teams in the open web community who have deep understanding of disempowered or vulnerable users?




### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** a9f2bc69-ac43-4272-a59e-4a343d3ef34b

**[ Session Name ]** Creating accessible stories on a deadline
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Joanna Kao
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Financial Times
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @joannaskao

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Muhammad Adnan


### What will happen in your session?
The media has unique accessibility challenges because of its quick pace and unpredictable content. This session will discuss best practices for web accessibility, graphics, closed captioning, and social media and facilitate a discussion about how we can improve accessibility on a deadline.

For the session, I will prepare a quick intro of what accessibility is, what it means and who it affects. Depending on the size of the group, we will break into smaller groups to tackle specific issues in the media — e.g. How can we provide closed captioning and transcripts on quick turnaround deadlines? How can we make interactive graphics more accessible? What tools can we use to make designing content accessible from the very beginning? 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
I hope people will leave thinking about ways to make their own work more accessible. For example, I hope people who create custom graphics will consider accessibility in their design process, and those who work on product teams can go home with tips for creating an overall more accessible website. At the very least, I think people will leave having a better understanding of how different people consume information, what accessibility means and why it is important (even for those outside of the media).




### Time needed
60 mins

title: Data Driven Journalism : IOT boards
body:
**[ UUID ]** 933bae71-570f-441e-9677-2930103731f2

**[ Session Name ]** Data Driven Journalism : IOT boards
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Rufus Chakravarthy Sharma






### What will happen in your session?
Data journalism can be best described as the use of large sets of data, and operations such as data filtering, processing and analysis for the purpose of creating "news" or "supplying customers with specific information". The rudiments of data driven journalism can be found in the older practices of computer assisted reporting or CAR, which was in vogue a few years earlier. It also derives heavily from other journalistic philosophies, particularly those which require the use of social science techniques in journalism.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The core of data journalism can be attributed to the instant and unencumbered availability of huge volumes of data which is available openly and for everyone on the internet. The concept of data journalism promises a whole new level of service to the consuming public and to business interests, with superior information, stories and content that can inspire smart decision-making.
Here our data is IOT boards and our story revolves around different types of IOT boards available, their capabilities, what they can do, what they can't, pros and cons. Which will bring "The high level contextual information about IOT boards", into the lights.
This will help many to choose the boards based upon their requirement and provides information about the alternatives too.



### Time needed
less than 60 mins

title: Chupadados, the Datasucker - hidden faces of our beloved technologies

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

body:
**[ UUID ]** 1cde5492-825c-4cbf-8b6e-1d28e865c5fa

**[ Session Name ]** Chupadados, the Datasucker - hidden faces of our beloved technologies
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Joana  Varon 
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Coding Rights
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @joana-varon

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Danae Tapia or Tati Dias


### What will happen in your session?
We love our technological devices, but we have enough evidence that we are now in an abusive relationship with them. We suspect that they might be possessed by Chupadatos, the Data Sucker. 

This session will use storytelling tools built at https://chupadados.codingrights.org/ to show how a context in which data is extracted in our daily relations with our CITIES, HOMES, POCKETS and even BODIES can ultimately lead to more inequality, segregation and to reinforce old power struggles that we already fight against, such as North/South asymmetries and issues of gender equality. 

Why does period trackers wanna know so much about your feelings? Who owns the data of your transportation card? Are pregnant women a specific target for trackers? 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want to dismantle fake dichotomies "privacy vs security" or "privacy vs innovation" using examples that illustrate our daily activities and the correlation with the importance of data protection. 

Our  ultimate goal is to promote usages and development of technologies with a critical vision on data, not in a prohibitive or totally dystopian way, which might take away our agency to do anything about it, but in a conscious way, to promote better practices from all the actors involved. 





### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
projector and sound


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Digital Inclusion Repository Demo: Sharing Materials & Building Community

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 421ae5b8-1148-4515-9684-c0da0ff55ac9

**[ Session Name ]** Digital Inclusion Repository Demo: Sharing Materials & Building Community
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Matthew Kopel
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** National Digital Inclusion Alliance





### What will happen in your session?
We're all working on building our community's capacity for digital inclusion, but too often it feels like we're working in a vacuum, reinventing the wheel over and over. This workshop will introduce participants to a new community driven, online digital inclusion repository platform, where they can submit their best documents and slides, remix community broadband plans, translate and localize curricula, and share out their best practices.

Participants will be given an overview of the platform’s origin and a walkthrough of how it works before we all dive in to discover and build new materials together. As this repository is a work in progress, feedback, ideas and critiques will be welcomed and documented for the future of the initiative.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants become engaged in the ecosystem of sharing and localizing digital inclusion materials. This platform is just as much about materials as it is about making connections across a community of practice. This session is about having a space to share out both digital assets and personal anecdotes, with the goal of helping people move their digital inclusion priorities forward.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Just an overhead projector should do it.


### Time needed
60 mins

title: The Very Hungry Code-a-pillar: coding with under 5s

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 45474d85-c0c4-4345-9420-646a17828513

**[ Session Name ]** The Very Hungry Code-a-pillar: coding with under 5s
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Amy Hearn
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Kirklees Libraries
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @amyhearn

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Krystal Vittles (Suffolk Libraries)


### What will happen in your session?
In this practical session we will discuss the importance of introducing children to the basics of coding, discover some of the ways public libraries are helping under 5s develop the skills needed for coding, and get hands on with some of the coding toys and games available for toddlers. Taking an action learning approach, participants will take a critical look at some of the ways public libraries have embedded the foundations of coding  into story times and nursery visits, and help libraries develop and improve our under 5s coding offer.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will leave this session with practical ideas of how to introduce toddlers to simple concepts like sequencing, critical thinking, and problem solving. They will understand the importance of helping young people develop essential coding skills from an early age and be given the skills needed to equip children in this way. Presenters will discover ways to develop and improve their under 5s coding offer.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Nothing additional. Presenters will bring a range of toys and resources aimed at under 5s.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 1dbb6cd5-dcc7-4512-b34b-db85c1b78fea

**[ Session Name ]** Alternative Manufacturing Futures (Open Session)
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Fi Duffy-Scott
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Make Works Ltd


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Elizabeth Malcolm,Daniel Powers


### What will happen in your session?
In this workshop, participants will explore how we can use the internet to create alternatives to our global mass manufacturing system. 

We will look at how the future of manufacturing relates to the environment, craft, internet of things, repair, the economy and the nature of work - collectively working out what we can do as citizens to ensure this moves in a healthy direction. 

After demonstrations of recent projects by Make Works, workshop participants will be introduced to the organisation's techniques in mapping, collecting and share data about manufacturers in their own geographical area. We’ll then move on to exploring ways that participants can start using the Make Works API to develop their own tools for distributed manufacturing. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
It can feel feel impossible as both citizens and consumers to have any real say in the way in how, who and where our electronic devices, clothing, homewares and other everyday objects are manufactured. What will happen if only a few corporations own our means of production? Why are we not given the ability to fix, repair or even access key components? What does that look like when these products are connected to the internet?

The goal of this session is to demonstrate the relevance of local production, and give participants additional internet tools that will allow them to take ownership of how and where the objects they use are made.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector for laptop
Internet access
Post-it notes, Paper, Sharpies 



### Time needed
90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 0261307c-be02-4ecf-8f99-2ceea5af8d2e

**[ Session Name ]** ExperiSensing Our World
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Tudor Cismarescu
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Technology Volunteers
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @WarwickTechVols

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Nathan Dunne,Kieran Hall,Alex Motoc,Chris Philp,Kaitlen Weaver,Margaret Low


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will be introduced to the abilities of the Arduino board and the ExperiSense shield, and shown how to interact with it through Scratch. They will build circuits with minimal wiring, using crocodile clips, and build games or other interactive applications controlled by physical sensors. Additionally, the physical principles on which these sensors are based will be introduced briefly.
The ExperiSense is an Arduino shield developed by student volunteers from the University of Warwick. It facilitates a wider range of projects to be used by educators to spark children's interest in technology.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of our session is to introduce participants to the exciting possibilities of several physical sensors. By removing the worry of the usual text-based programming necessary for Arduino projects, children will be more open towards these interesting projects. By simplifying the wiring of sensors, the creative process is streamlined, so participants will experience the possbilities of using these sensors with fewer obstacles to overcome.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Each participant must bring a laptop to take part.


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Putting professionals at the heart of education in the internet age

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** cb444b91-5abd-467b-894b-e97282b4c8d0

**[ Session Name ]** Putting professionals at the heart of education in the internet age
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Martin Hawksey
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Association for Learning Technology
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @mhawksey

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Maren Deepwell,Bryan Mathers


### What will happen in your session?
There is a danger that edtech is becoming lost in the ‘Silicon Valley Narrative’, controlled by the powerful few, it’s history and research rewritten to fit other agendas. In this workshop we focus on how we can build a less dystopian future of education, exploring how we can put people, and more specifically educators, at the heart of learning, teaching and assessment with technology. As part of this we will introduce the work of the Association for Learning Technology (ALT), its strategy and how its members have a space to contribute to the development of edtech. An important aspect of this is recognizing our members contributions. We will share work on our expanding accreditation scheme for participate discussion and contribution.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The main part of the workshop will introduce CMALT, ALT’s accreditation scheme, which has been designed to meet these challenges. By recognising skills and experience related to technology in general, but not specific software or tools, the scheme has established itself as a robust accreditation framework for professionals whose role involves edtech. Now we are seeking to expand the framework. Workshop participants will be able to examine the pilot of this new project and participate in the open, collaborative work to expand the framework.  We want to practically explore how we empower professionals who work in education to make use of the internet and technology more broadly to help meet some of the biggest challenges in education. 



### Time needed
60 mins
