body:
**[ UUID ]** c4d5b0a2-a119-40e1-bed0-0f9f943825ba

**[ Session Name ]** Disrupting Health and Fitness Technology
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Diane Scott
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** AHRC Digital Transformations Theme, University of Glasgow 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @lguariento

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Helen Manchester,Antonia Liguori 


### What will happen in your session?
In our session participants will have the opportunity to learn about and interact with digital technologies and methods which are being co-designed by researchers and people with disabilities, older people and/or those who are ill. The session will show how digital storytelling apps are being used by people with sight and/or hearing impairments. We will also discuss projects which are developing ways to incorporate social care into digital technology, and how tangible technologies and creative methods and inventions are helping people with dementia. The session is open to all ages and does not require technical expertise. Come along, chat to researchers, try out some tech – and help brainstorm new ideas for health technologies which are clever, creative and inclusive!

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Often perceptions and discussions of the role of technology in the area of health are focused on wearables, fitness tracking, and ‘wellness’ apps which can help plan exercise routines, suggest healthy meals and record sleep patterns. Our session aims to disrupt these perceptions of health technology by discussing and demonstrating how technology can be developed and used in relation to care, illness and/or disability. In addition, our session will highlight the importance of creative thinking and co-designing when developing new ideas, methods and solutions. Inclusion can and should begin with the development process! 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We would like a projector, post-it notes and pens. If possible, we would also like speakers so that we can play videos on the projector. 


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Building a Privacy browser extension

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @jonathanKingston




### What will happen in your session?
We will be walking through some of the extensions we have build internally to outline the potential of extensions with a focus of privacy. Participants will be focused on the privacy and security benefits that could be made possible now with the APIs we now expose.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
People will learn to hack on the new web extensions and build their own extensions. Participants will learn about extensions we have worked on and the potential of the platform for their own. As security is always a hard balance we may see some neat innovation that we didn't think of internally.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Whiteboard + pens, projector + vga cable / mini display port connector. Potentially loaner machines.

90 mins

### What will happen in your session?
This will be a session to think about how to make the Code For Life (codeforlife.education) project even more diverse and inclusive.
Code For Life was created in 2014 by volunteers at Ocado to provide free, open source games and teaching materials to primary schools, clubs and beyond. We focus on logical thinking, and we want all children to feel inspired and confident about technology from a young age.
We will describe the project, what we are currently doing to make it inclusive and to promote digital literacy, but will also have a session with attendees to find ideas to improve our project.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to have everyone take the real life example of our project, which has more than 100000 registered users and already promotes digital literacy and inclusion, and all together come up with ideas and actions to make it even better accessible and diversity focused. In the end, we could get ideas, or even have some actions already started (translations, UX mockups...)

A projector to showcase our game and games in progress.
(A whiteboard would be great if possible?)
We'll also need sheets of paper (Some A0 or A1 if possible but also some A2 or A3), pens, post-it notes (of different colours if possible), blutack if we don't have a whiteboard as we'll paste some paper on the wall...

**[ UUID ]** 2e670404-d16c-46b6-8a68-36ad2aefe271

**[ Session Name ]** demoVRacy
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** BUSHRA  BURGE 
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Bushra Burge Studio


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Sonia Ali ,Mark Bean


### What will happen in your session?
Currently VR is controlled and experienced by a very narrow demographic of society. Do we want this to be yet another medium which follows a particular path by established exclusive voices ? 
The session will explore the notion of over-engineering reality versus subtle engagement and acceptance for a group experience : 
- introductory lecture 
- team briefs of future scenarios to think within the framework of speculative design by using:
structured experiential experiments and demonstrations with participants using multisensory (haptics, acoustic controlled, 360 animated visuals) technologies made at Bushra Burge Studio
- considering illusion experiments particularly as part of the worn experience, agency, self and the collective as consensus.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The outcome is to breakdown the elitist context VR and multi-sensory experience operates. The technology and associated experiences are made by and for a very small slice of society.
Therefore the outcome is to facilitate :
- participants to learn through experimentation with the different sensory stimulations as independent components and as a holistic experience 
- to allow for their own critical analysis of sensory and physical augmentation through worn technology
- to empower different voices and perspectives to lead on sensory design ideas which are currently being controlled by heavily funded corporates or very niche artists. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Please provide projector and mannequins to place haptic costumes. Projector, notepads, pens.




### Time needed
90 mins

### What will happen in your session?
From previsionary ideas like the Memex and bidirectional hyperlinks, to current browser/editor experiments and read/write web protocols, we will explore old and new visions of a web of knowledge in which the readers are also the creators and connectors of the web.

While discussing these topics, we will put the ideas into practice and start linking up and annotating related documents on the web, to collectively contribute our knowledge to the web (using a read/write browser (extension) such as WebMemex, Beaker browser, Dokieli or Hypothes.is).

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
People should leave with a broader view of the history of the web and a glimpse of its possible future, and current possibilities to add links and pages to the web from within their browsers. Also, we will have made a small contribution to the knowledge on the web, about the web.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.

**[ Session Name ]** Inkscape and Lasercutting - come make some jewellery or a keyring.
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Amy Mather

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @MiniGirlGeek




### What will happen in your session?
Participants will be learning how to use Inkscape (open source design program) to create a geeky jewellery / keyring design. Other options include coasters etc.

I will then be able to fabricate it on the lasercutter using acrylic or plywood. 

They can then come back at the end of the day to finish it off by attaching a chain, keyring or magnet etc.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Will encourage people to find out more about how they can create their own things, and shows them the sorts of things they can make at their local hack/makespace and how they can use open source software to create their designs. Making more mini makers :D


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Requires, plywood, acrylic, necklace chains, jump rings and pliers etc. However youthzone already owns these materials as it didn't all get used last year. I think we need to order some more keyrings though.

I will require access to the lasercutter upstairs at ravensbourne, the participants will need access to computers with inkscape on - last year we had PiTops in the protyping space but we could be located anywhere. I will also require a big screen to show a presentation on with demos of inkscape.


### Time needed
90 mins

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Georgia Bullen
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** New America's Open Technology Institute // Measurement Lab
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @georgiamoon

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Chris Ritzo,Kasia Odrozek,Solana Larsen


### What will happen in your session?
Measurement Lab would like to work with the Internet Health Report team to create an interactive gallery space around internet health data. The M-Lab team will prepare an interactive data exploration for MozFest attendees to explore and contribute information about their experience on the internet, to engage participants in the issues around infrastructure, access, and additional pillars from the Internet Health Report, depending on what the team wants to add. This proposal is meant as a placeholder so that we can expand with Kasia & Solana.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Engage MozFest participants in data about the health of the internet. Allow for participants to contribute to the gallery space through some interactive engagement, and explore other participants submissions. We may also have some scheduled time in our gallery space to work with participants to build raspberry pi internet testing probes, which people could them take home and set to run tests regularly and contribute to the open data on internet health.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We may need a project or screens for the gallery space. I can update this later this week with information about what we'd expect to need.

Office supplied, I think we will need push pins, pens, post-its and cardboard boxes.

For the internet testing devices (mini session idea in the gallery space), we could bring some devices, but we'd be interested in partnering in some way to have devices that people could take home with them, or potentially having a prize of some sort for who can take home some of the devices we bring. 


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Social Media and Expression

milestone.title: Youth Zone
milestone.description:
**Space description**
For our collective sake
Let your passion create a story
Let your passion design the day
Let that passion fight the cause
Let our voice be heard

The Youth Zone is like a poem—creative, unexpected, powerful. Join this space for youth leaders and their mentors who are creating art, technology and positive social change. From a Raspberry Pi-coded singing potato to our fireside chat on Internet health, come explore our collective tomorrow.

**[ UUID ]** a74cbdcf-a9c6-403b-a524-f7ba16277c09

**[ Session Name ]** Social Media and Expression
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Catherine Hearne
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Helix Arts


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Katie Jayne Appleyard,Animation artist tbc,Catherine Hearne


### What will happen in your session?
Katie Jayne Appleyard will lead a session ‘The Real You?’ exploring Social Media and Expression as part of the collaboration strand for Off the Beat - Helix Arts Youth Music project.
The group will:
•	reflect how they share via social media and how they curate themselves on differing platforms and why?
•	under-go a micro session in an art form eg animation and complete a challenge 
•	work in pairs/ small group to respond on different specific social media outputs 
•	use this stimulus to create a small digital artwork to represent their versions 
•	review the process to explore what they share and how they adapted it for the intended social media platform
•	share films during the process (Streaming during/posting after the session)


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
‘The Real You?’ would focus on delivering an film/animation based workshop exploring how different groups express feelings whether it be happiness, anger, sadness or any array of the emotions on offer into purposeful or meaningful route for communication and collaboration.

Background discussion may include: When does expression become overload of information which you really don’t need or want to know? What does social media really present to you? Respond artistically!

Further reach and awareness for Off the Beat and wider collaborative partners/networks are attracted.

Available:  Arts Award Discover Part A) Taking Part in animation Part B) Collect artist fact sheets Part C) Share process and product via chosen and wider online social media #therealyou 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
-Laptops/Macs
-Plasma or screen to show 'How Tos)
-Flip chart (desirable)

We can provide if unavailable. Just trying to travel light!


### Time needed
90 mins

title: A.R.A Husk

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

**[ UUID ]** ad78df99-bbcf-45f4-9ced-d57ea554ab51

**[ Session Name ]** Trading futures, fixing bugs: a live Smart Contracts installation
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Don Marti
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** dmarti

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Rich Bodo,Andy Leak,


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will interact with a live decentralized market where they can trade “futures contracts” on the outcome of software bugs. Everyone will be able to join in, from the user’s own browser or one of our trading stations, and choose from a variety of activities.

 * Post new bug reports on a simple repository

 * “Invest” cryptocurrency in your prediction of a bug’s resolution

 * Contribute pull requests and comments to the repository

 * Watch your “market position,” and the market in general, change with bug status, and trades by other participants

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will increase their understanding of how market mechanisms can enable participants in a collaborative project to share information, and how bug futures compare to other organizational tools such as crowdfunding and crowdsourcing. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
 * 2 or more demo stations with browser

 * Large monitor for browser running market charts and ticker

This could all fit on a medium to large table. It would be good to have a stand for the monitor showing charts, to help attract participants who are exploring the “openness” space.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

body:
**[ UUID ]** 190df20c-9f57-4be1-9d64-29fdf2de41af

**[ Session Name ]** Blockchain for humanity: rapid prototyping workshop
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Kate Dodgson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** HumanityX
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @LU-C4i




### What will happen in your session?
Participants will address a humanitarian problem and explore whether blockchain can offer a solution. The workshop will follow a rapid prototyping methodology which involves short, time-boxed activities designed to pick apart and probe the context of the problem, and the technological possibilities of the solution.

Plan International will present the user case: should birth registrations in Bangladesh be recorded in blockchain? Participants will be split into groups and the activities will require them to consider necessity, feasibility, desirability, scalability and incentive to use blockchain for birth registrations. The activities are designed so that by the end of the session, fifteen basic prototypes have been created. The three most feasible will then be further elaborated on and judged against criteria.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This workshop benefits technologists and humanitarians alike. It allows techies to understand the humanitarian context their products will be applied to and allows the humanitarian sector to explore how and whether blockchain could be used in their organisations. 

The activities and iterations force participants to consider blockchain contextually – whether the technology could work in a country such as Bangladesh, whether people would actually use it, whether they have the equipment and expertise to maintain it, and whether it’s worth the development costs. HumanityX is not a blockchain company, therefore have no vested interest in organisations choosing to use blockchain. Helping them decide NOT to use it is of just as much value.



### Time needed
90 mins

title: Learn it,Make it,Map it with OSM (open street mapping)

title: Autonomous technologies for feminist action

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 12cf7f6b-af27-406b-961a-57589d84f73d

**[ Session Name ]** Autonomous technologies for feminist action
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Danae Tapia
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Riseup Networks
**[ Submitter's Github ]** danaevalentina




### What will happen in your session?
I will present selected Latin American cases of feminist groups using autonomous Internet services for their actions, like providing information for safe abortion through secure email, communications before protests using secure mailing lists and private wikis, the creation of music, podcasts, and art with open source software.
I am part of Riseup Networks (riseup.net) and I will show how our services are used by these groups, my intention is to facilitate a critical discussion on the intersection of technologies and non-white feminism. From that point, the participants will contribute with their own stories and we will put ourselves in the situation of a feminist activist and create a plan of action using secure technologies, evaluating the threats and understanding her options.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We will understand the importance of automonous technologies for feminism and other activisms.



### Time needed
60 mins

title: Digital Braves - using Drama to explore digital issues of identity, creativity and privacy in our society's future.

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** fa058b9d-3fab-4a5b-a65b-3231a625f291

**[ Session Name ]** Digital Braves - using Drama to explore digital issues of identity, creativity and privacy in our society's future.
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Mick Chesterman
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Floss Manuals / Manchester Met University
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @mickfuzz

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Alison Ramsey,Becky Patterson


### What will happen in your session?
We will set up a drama where participants become involved in a scenario of increased automation and information surveillance. The drama is based around “The Network” a technocratic world 20 minutes into the future. 

Participants learn about this world by becoming involved in an interactive process to screen them for their preferences and divide them accordingly into two separate teams (Creatives or Consumers) based on their resulting personality attributes. 

Teams are then given role play missions to complete which involves cracking a code and altering the messages contained in the fabric of the Network’s communication structure. The final mission is to remix a Mozilla Thimble project to create their own advert to support or subvert the system. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
One goal is to give participants hands on experience of coding HTML and creating their own web pages as a means of self-expression and empowerment by hands of use of digital technology. We use and promote Mozilla’s Thimble tool to do this. 

However, the primary goal is to explore issues of privacy in an accessible way also involving the emotional participation of the people taking part. We are applying the techniques pioneered by Drama specialist Dorothy Heathcote known as ‘Mantle of the Expert’ to the area of digital rights and learning to code. The immersive drama we have designed brings participants into a fictional ‘brotherhood of ideas’ making concrete some of the more abstract concepts of digital security and profiling.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
none needed


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** c36726d4-f2b2-4faa-9593-65d483a93498

**[ Session Name ]** HOW CAN LINGUISTICS HELP A HEALTHY INTERNET?
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Andrew Prescott
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Glasgow


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Diane Scott


### What will happen in your session?
How voice control is implemented is a vital issue for the future health of the internet. Concern that large corporations will restrict access to voice training data has led Mozilla to launch its Common Voice project to create open voice recognition training data. We work in one of the leading English Language and Linguistics Department in the UK. Researchers in our Department collect information about how English and Scots is spoken and analyse its linguistic characteristics. They also study how the voice works. In this session, linguistic researchers will explain how they collect information about our voice and language. We will discuss whether there are opportunities to collaborate with Mozilla’s initiatives over Voice Control.      

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want participants to learn about the range of resources created by linguistic researchers. These include open resources such as the Historical Thesuarus of the Engish Language and the Scots National Corpus. We want to build links between linguistic researchers and those working in Mozilla's Open IoT Studio and elsewhere, to see whether linguistics resources can help create more open voice control of the internet. At present, there is little contact between these researchers or awareness of potential links, and a MozFest session is a perfect opportunity to build these links. We also want to promote awareness of the fascinating research done by linguistic researchers and encourage everyone to take more interest in it.    


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Some loudspeakers or access to a sound system would be very helpful, as well as a projector.


### Time needed
90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 2f85595f-6c53-44b6-82a9-95f26569b627

**[ Session Name ]** Let's make an Open Science exhibition ! 
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Bianca Kramer
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Utrecht University / 101 Innovations in Scholarly Communication
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @bmkramer

**[ Additional facilitators ]** (1 person, to be determined)


### What will happen in your session?
At this session, we will design an Open Science exhibition. By making all aspects of research openly available, often by use of online web technology and innovations, science can be made open to participation, open to reuse and open to the world. So far though, discussions around open science have mostly been limited to the level of research institutions and policy making. 

To involve the general public in open science, we want to generate ideas for an open science exhibition. We want to show the beauty and benefits of open science, but such an exhibition can also adress issues of privacy and anonymity. We will brainstorm ideas, but also explore the floors of Mozfest for inspiration.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We will not create an open science exhibition itself at Mozfest, but collect ideas on activities and logistics (a blueprint) for people to organize such an exhibition anywhere they choose. Activities can include ideas for visitors to share research ideas, contribute data, doing analyze existing data (including data visualization), and translate research findings for a more general audience. Logistics can include ideas for contacting researchers to participate, creative use of space, and financing and publicity.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Posterboard(s) with tacks/pins will be useful. No electronic equipment required for this one. 


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Busting Oligopolies With Three Sided Marketplaces

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** 4a4b8ff3-981b-4280-9201-2ec44fb76586

**[ Session Name ]** Busting Oligopolies With Three Sided Marketplaces
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Josh Harris
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** VarageSale
**[ Submitter's Github ]** jharris1679




### What will happen in your session?
We will discuss ideas, surrounding how marketplaces can both create and dismantle monopolies and oligopolies, drawing on examples from recent times. I will propose that all marketplaces in fact have three sides; providers, consumers, and facilitators. The pros and cons of human vs AI facilitators will surely come up.

Problems arising from modern leading marketplaces will be addressed, such as wealth imbalance, over-stimulation of the masses, and the growing burden of choice. Ideas for how the same innovative forces can be directed to produce healthier outcomes will be brought forward, namely how decentralizing the third side to many marketplaces allows for richer (more diverse) outcomes in the system. 



### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The primary goal will be to conceptually develop a leading alternative to large media platforms as the sole distributors of advertising; under the assumption that this centralized model leads to over-stimulated and dis-enfranchised consumers, as well as wasted marketing budgets that accumulate in oligopolies.

Some early propositions to guide the discussion:
 - matching small/medium companies with complimentary offerings to each other, so that they each can benefit from the other's reach
 - creating and empowering individual "curators" of information, for easier consumption by certain groups of people. Think newsletters, which take a whole space worth of information and deliver the most important bits to interested readers.

The secondary goal would be to begin laying the technical design for implementing a proposed solution.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
No additional needs.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ UUID ]** 5c3d1e35-1ac1-4f05-a8fa-40eb460a5955

**[ Session Name ]** Empowerment through Security & Digital Literacy directed to native (indigenous) women's communities 
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Liza  Durón
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** México (Mozilla club)
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @elidron

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Alejandro Gómez


### What will happen in your session?
Assistants will understand the different training activities we are carrying out in collaboration with the Mexico's President office for Digitat education & strategy to identify local security and privacy issues in each country's state and with native communities of vulnerable women. Each state has a problem of violence that starts on the internet and affects online and real life security that fuels the digital divide in these communities.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Understand the appropriate methodology to address issues of digital divide in indigenous communities to eradicate violence on and off the internet. It is important to know (in depth) the types of violence that these communities live in. Because of this, numbers keep growing and lack of education in security issues is the key point to the permanence of this problem. 

Project: https://elidron.github.io/womenobservatory/en.html


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A projector is needed. 


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Is That Real?: Preparing Students to Outfox Fake News

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 32b85722-8d25-41e3-b4ae-df82251757e8

**[ Session Name ]** Is That Real?: Preparing Students to Outfox Fake News
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sarah FitzHenry
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** St. Anne's-Belfield School


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Kim Wilkens


### What will happen in your session?
Attendees will work through a series of games, activities, and challenges that will help them see the issue of fake news from a student’s perspective. Our Foiling Fake News Teaching Kit builds off our students’ previously mastered website verification skills, putting these skills into the new context of online current event reporting - blogs, news and fact-checking websites, satirical news sources, and more. Using Mozilla tools like Kraken the Code and X-ray Goggles, participants will get hands-on experience with lessons designed to help young people become more educated and confident internet news consumers. More details about the lessons can be found @ https://thimbleprojects.org/techkim/258242.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our goal is to make sure that information and digital literacy skills are constantly practiced and reviewed by parents, educators, librarians and anyone who works with children. In order to help students to learn how to find the best information online, we want to help educators feel comfortable taking a step back and letting students take control, and Mozilla has provided a fantastic set of tools that empowers them to do just that.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will require a projector and pens for our session. We will not need any additional materials.


### Time needed
60 mins

title: 10 Words Died on the Internet and What Happened Next is Shocking
body:
**[ UUID ]** 54eb304c-cd06-49b7-98a2-8c61384bde0d

**[ Session Name ]** 10 Words Died on the Internet and What Happened Next is Shocking
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Brian 'Dyalekt' Kushner
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Pockets Change
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @dyalekt

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Pamela Capalad


### What will happen in your session?
This show is a guided tour Hip Hop Theater art installation about the way we talk to each other online. I recently noticed that I was unable to have productive conversations or arguments that contained certain words (racism, feminism et al) because we no longer have a shared understanding of what those words mean, so arguments devolve into fights. I spent over a year researching internet comments (strictly semi-anonymous article comments, no forums or social media) and found 10 words that have died, or lost all meaning and only exist to win or start fights. I will be guiding an audience around a museum of dead words dressed in their finest fonts, with beats & rhymes illuminating the path.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
I know it's cliché to type that I'm looking to spark conversation and create awareness, but that's exactly what this project is designed to do. More specifically, the idea is to hip us to words and phrases that are no longer useful in our typed conversations. The typed word lacks the emotion that sound or handwriting give us, so agreed upon meanings are critical to productive conversation and overall literacy in the digital age. Building capability requires understanding the new context, which requires noticing that there is a new context. Participants will walk away with tools to create more specificity in their online conversations and recognize when there is a need for it.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will provide most of the materials, but will need space (preferably with a couple rooms, but we're flexible) and a place where we can mount some visual pieces. We'll need a cordless or lav mic and PA system. If you can't provide any of the the equipment, we're prepared to rent it. We will also be hiring someone local to oversee sound & stage manage. 


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

body:
**[ UUID ]** cd55b982-214f-43e8-8f53-4826843523c7

**[ Session Name ]** Smiley Pursuit
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Metod Blejec
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** n/a
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @metodb

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Una Rebic


### What will happen in your session?
“Smiley Pursuit” introduces a design thinking process to spark and expand visual literacy in kids, their parents and other festival goers. At a game—a real life “augmented” reality—participants will be challenged with a fun and creative scavenger hunt while learning to see things when looking. Working in teams of 3 the gamers will hunt for faces-in-places and frame as many of them with masking tape. Whether smiling, sad, bewildered, angry, annoyed, surprised, cheeky…, each guerrilla framing of a smiley (face-in-place) at Mozilla Festival brings one point. In a form of snapped photographs, whichever team collects most points in 90min wins the game and the challenge trophy.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The aim of the “Smiley Pursuit” challenge is to encourage visual literacy through design thinking in a fun and creative workshop format. The goal of this session is to draw upon participants’ intuition, imagination and creativity while exploring possibilities of what could be a great and innovative capture of a face-in-place. Outcomes of the session will be many creative and silly pictures of smileys ready to be posted as original content on participants’ social media feeds. Furthermore, once being attuned to seeing faces-in-places participants will not be able to ignore hundreds of them in their everyday. The team which collects the most points will take home a trophy for winning the challenge. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
The session will require or equip participants with several weapons: tape, camera and a felt tip marker. Coloured masking tape (for easy removal) will help us frame faces-in-places. Each team will need at least one digital camera for collecting what they have been hunting down and a felt tip markers to sign each smiley with a group name. The session requires only some coloured felt tip markers from Mozilla Festival. I assume at least one person in the group will have a digital camera. The rest will be provided by me. Let the games begin!


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Let’s Play with Rust: A Friendly Introduction

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

title: Voices of the Amazon - Building a digital collective in the "lung of the earth" rainforest

labels.name: Other: Portuguese and Tupy Guarany (some parts)

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 80e5c71c-1ec1-4e6f-9427-b6e4689b8880

**[ Session Name ]** Voices of the Amazon - Building a digital collective in the "lung of the earth" rainforest
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Renata Aquino Ribeiro
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** E. I. Research
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @renataaquino

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Renata Kelly dos Santos,Gilmar Mazurkievicz,


### What will happen in your session?
This session will help build a digital collective in the Amazon rainforest region with the contribution of participants at Mozilla Festival. This will be done by hands-on projects and conversation online w/ tribes. The Amazon rainforest covers 9 countries in the northern South America and is indicated to be responsible for 50% of the oxygen of the world. So a group of activists, teachers and policymakers will be joined in this session to try and bring a digital collective to the "lung of the earth". The proposers of this session already articulate universities, schools and indigenous populations into a momentum to bring consciousness about the weight and value of Amazon voices to the world. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Give voices and projects to people interested in the Amazon region to ally freedom, technology and consciousness about climate change is the goal of this session, achievable by building a digital collective in the region. This will be done via documenting conversations via video, social media, creating apps and art installations on the Amazon voices perspectives. Investing heavily in integrating onsite and online participation, proposers want to bring indigenous tribes of the Amazon to talk to participants via video and to give feedback on their projects and ideas on a section called "Conversations with Amazonian indigenous and local native population". The idea is Mozilla Festival participants can come to our session/lounge and talk to the population in scheduled times.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We usually work w/ little to nothing so we need nothing. Whatever is given, though, we can use. It would be good to have a nice projector and a screen so people can see the Amazonians well. But we'll likely use mobile messaging too so if we don't have it, it's fine.



### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ UUID ]** 45d8c066-583b-4876-935e-df13d37ff412

**[ Session Name ]** Automatic Twitter photo booth with the Raspberry Pi
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Vincent Lee
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Northern Ireland Raspberry Jam
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @vlee489

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Sam Stuart,Claire Mulholland,June He


### What will happen in your session?
This is a workshop revolving around using the Raspberry Pi with a PIR (Passive Infra-Red) sensor, connected to the Raspberry Pi’s GPIO. When the PIR detects motion, it will trigger a photo to be taken with the Raspberry Pi Camera Module. Then the Pi will upload the photo along with a pre-set message to the participant’s Twitter account, using the twitter API implementation for Python.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The outcome of this session is to have the participants learn how to use the Twitter Python API, which allows them to get to grips with the basics of how to post tweets onto twitter and how to add media using the API. Our goal is to give kids an introduction into coding and showing them how they can interact with other services that they may use on a daily basis, and how they can make programs that can communicate with the outside world.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
- Raspberry Pi
- Screen
- Keyboard
- Mice
- PIR sensor (1 Per Pi)
- Female to Female jumper cable (3 Per Pi)
- Raspberry Pi Camera Module (1 Per Pi)



### Time needed
60 mins

**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Erase All Kittens
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @DrumRollHQ

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Dhiresh Nathwani,Leonie Van Der Linde,Priya Nirmal


### What will happen in your session?
The E.A.K. Mini Game Jam session will introduce children aged 8-14 to creative coding and computational thinking in the context of interactive storytelling and game design. For the first 30 minutes, participants will be given access to the full version of E.A.K. and will be introduced to the basics of HTML via story-driven gameplay. For the remaining 30 minutes, we will discuss several key aspects of the game design process, such as the story, game mechanics and character design, and participants will work together in groups of 2-3, to brainstorm ideas for games.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
At the end of the workshop, participants will feel inspired to use interactivity in media and learn more about the creative potential of computing. They will have looked at a number of different methods of interactive storytelling and game design, and will be familiar with the basics of programming using syntax. We aim to inspire young children, particularly girls, to want to learn more about coding, in a creative 'real-world' context, since there is currently far more of a focus on computational thinking, for this age-group.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We would require paper and coloured pens, and also 8-10 laptops/chargers if possible!

(we have two machines available and trying to secure at least eight more)



### Time needed
60 mins

**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** South London Rasppberry jam


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Grace Owolade-Coombes,Marc Grossman


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will be given an introduction to the MicroBit with an ice breaker and then given a simple task to flash code on to the Microbit. The second part of the challenge will involve teams using the Robo:Bit Buggy, downloading the BitBot library to complete increasingly difficult challenges.

The first challenge - go forward, pause and then go back to starting point
The second challenge will be to complete a perfect square - to arrive back at starting point
The final task is use the Line-following sensors to complete a timed course

The ultimate challenge is to code another Microbit to control the Robo:Bit Buggy using the accelerometer and radio control features.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The aim of the session is to introduce the MicroBit to participants and show how they can be used to come robots. The Ice Breaker and team tasks aim to encourage interaction and collaboration.

We will need laptops/Pi Tops or PC to access Micro:Bit website

If Micro:Bits are available (i.e.. through Code Club, Coderdojo) - then that would help too.

### What will happen in your session?
Mozilla’s contributors from all over the world do and outstanding work by spreading the word about Mozilla’s mission within their communities.  However, most of the times these leaders have very limited resources to lead their events and campaigns. 

In this session we will explore case studies about Club leaders who have done a great job on a very low budget. We will have some Hands on activities on how to build a Toolkit for campaigns (Web Literacy, activism, advocacy), and we’ll finally share a Repo with available resources:

### What will happen in your session?
The first 30 minutes will be a presentation on learning art and programming at the same time. We can take techniques normally used when programming, such as creating a basic outline of your system, and apply them to drawing: creating a small thumbnail of the idea before starting drawing. We can also take techniques used in drawing, like using transparent paper on top of drawings to let your art teacher correct them, and see how they are similar to code reviews.

Following that, participants will be asked to take a program they made or like and transform it into art (or vice versa). Examples of ways to do that will be given. Afterward, participants will be able to present their work.

**[ UUID ]** 12991a0e-a53a-4d95-9553-51dcf4c25522

**[ Session Name ]** B.A.-BA Pi - Les bases de Raspberry Pi & des jeux de Mo(zilla) 
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Alan McCullagh
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @tyrower

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Sebastien Rocca,
   
# English  
   
### What will happen in your session?

We'll (re)discover together the Raspberry Pi, initially dreamt up as an educational platform, by looking back at its history, its origins.
Next we'll familiarise ourselves with it use at the most simple level.
Then we'll explore the possibilities which are opened to us as a "swiss-army-knife" type tool helping us discover the world of FLOSS ('Free/Libre Open Source Software').

Ideally the possibility of doing this session in the context of a workshop (with 10-20 Raspberry Pi/Pi-Tops) but could also be presented as a conference/presentation.

[I can easily hold this session in English and/or in French]

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?

To help discover the functions of the Raspberry Pi and more generally the wealth of opportunities available to launch oneself into the world of GNU/Linux and all its free/libre ecosystem. To be able to exchange with participants about their existing knowledge and to motivate them to go further, whatever there current level of involvement or usage.

### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.

At bare minimum, I would be able to present just with my computer and a projector.

But ideally, I will use the PiTops from the "champions" : Andrew Mulholland, Cat Lamin, etc... for the session so as to be able to have a more "Hands on" spirit for the participants! That would imply the electrical installation (extensions, multiple adapters, etc) and peripheral devices (keyboard, mouse) but not necessarily internet access or other materials.

People can also explore this universe via there own computers (for instance the Raspbian Desktop x86 distribution) if needs be.
   
   
# French
   
   
### What will happen in your session?
Nous (re-)découvrons ensemble le Raspberry Pi, initialement conçu comme plateforme éducative, en passant par son histoire, ses origines.
Ensuite nous entamons une familiarisation de son fonctionnement au plus simple. 
Puis nous explorons les possibilités qui s'ouvrent à nous en considérant le potentiel du "nano-ordinateur à la framboise" comme couteau suisse menant vers le monde du FLOSS ('Free/Libre Open Source Software').

Idéalement la possibilité de faire dans le contexte d'un atelier (avec une dizaine-vingtaine de Raspberry Pi/Pi-Top) mais pourrait aussi être présenté comme conférence/présentation. 

[Je peux faire cette session facilement en Anglais et en Français]

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Faire découvrir le Raspberry Pi et plus généralement la richesse des opportunités disponible quand on se lance dans le monde de GNU/Linux et tout son écosystème libre. Pouvoir échanger avec les gens sur leurs connaissances existantes et les motiver d'aller plus loin, peu n'importe leur niveau d'implication actuel.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Je peux faire ma présentation juste avec mon ordinateur et un projecteur. 

Idéalement, j'utiliserai éventuellement les PiTops des "champions" : Andrew Mulholland, Cat Lamin, etc... pour la session pour pouvoir faire un vrai esprit de "Travaux Pratiques" aussi pour les participants ! Du coup, ça implique installation électrique (rallonges, multiprises, etc) et des périphériques (clavier, souris) mais pas obligatoirement accès internet ou d'autres matériaux. 

Les gens peuvent explorer également cet univers via leurs propres ordinateurs pendant la session, si besoin est. 


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Product development to support rural women entrepreneurs

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 2eea48dc-1d24-4e78-92f0-000c20899916

**[ Session Name ]** Product development to support rural women entrepreneurs 
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Pilar Harris
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** New York University (student) 





### What will happen in your session?
During my session, participants will draw from a 'hat' the profile of a woman entrepreneur in the developing world. Each profile will list the woman's geographic location, nationality, estimated income, languages spoken, literacy level, and the type of business she is running. 

In groups (or as individuals), participants will ideate a smartphone app that is suitable to the woman's needs with the objective of supporting the growth of her business. 

We will then share our app ideas and discuss some of the challenges associated with delivering product in developing communities. Some of the common challenges, based on my field experience, include lack of electricity, little to no network/WiFi access, and gender bias in terms of smartphone ownership. 



### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
There are two main goals of this session. 

First, participants would carefully (re)consider the role of digital technology in the lives of rural women. We will debate the question of whether technology is an appropriate tool in a rural context. How do women gain access to digital technology? What are their livelihood activities? What are their concerns, needs, and desires? 

Second, participants would practice problem solving and creative thinking by designing for first-time smartphone users. We will arrive at a better understanding of some of the barriers that the next 3-4 billion internet users will face as they come online via smartphone. 



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
No additional materials required


### Time needed
less than 60 mins

title: The European CO2 market : scraping with Python, and looking for ghost plants !

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:

**[ Session Name ]** The European CO2 market : scraping with Python, and looking for ghost plants !
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ana Lutzky
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** AEF
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @anouchk




### What will happen in your session?
// 30 minutes
Did you know there was a European CO2 market ? Want to learn about it and see how we built a scraper to analyze it? Come, I'll show you how to dive into its data. At my news agency AEF, we looked for an answer to the question : Who is really in control of the European CO2 market?  The investigation showed that 40 big companies are holding back their governments on CO2 market regulation. 

// 60 minutes
Hands-on workshop. Let's unite forces and explore CO2 trade in 31 countries in Europe. Fancy improving the python scraper to leverage fresh 2016 data? Do you prefer focusing on Polish/Greek/German coal plants? Or digging up the "ghost plants" ?

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to share awareness about European CO2 market, and also enable developers and journalists to work together during a workshop. It can end up in a European collaboration. 

Let's talk about our experiences in this area and - if interested - exchange mail addresses to start a network and keep in touch. 





### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Just a projector and wifi should be fine.


### Time needed
90 mins

**[ UUID ]** 4729a1b1-e72b-474b-bf7e-5b4e5372f543

**[ Session Name ]** Broadening the Tech Pipeline
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Nicole Frapolly
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** ChickTech Chicago
**[ Submitter's Github ]** ChicagoChickTech

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Katie SanFilippo,Janice Levenhagen 


### What will happen in your session?
ChickTech’s session will bring together the global tech community attending MozFest to brainstorm, discuss, network and collaborate with one another. This will be done through a series of interactive drop-in sessions, moderated by ChickTech, challenging the community to help solve real world barriers to expanding the tech pipeline. Each day a new Mind Map will be started to address one current barrier to the tech pipeline and participants will join the breakout discussions or put their thoughts directly, via puzzle piece, on the Challenge Wall.  We will encourage the attendees to help identify challenge areas and come up with creative solutions together.  Through this, barriers will be broken as we create in-roads to education and training for everyone.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of these sessions are to inspire attendees to apply what they have learned as they identify the challenges they face in making tech accessible to all locally. We also want all attends to walk away knowing there is community support to aid in brainstorming solutions after they return home from the conference. By talking and working together, every participant will come up with solutions needed in their local area by drawing upon ideas shared from the Mozilla global community. This area is meant to bring innovation by enabling others to lead the discussion and add to their personal tool kits by collaborating with others in the community with different expertise.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will be bringing 3 blank, numbered Wall size magnetic puzzles, Custom Signage, 3 wall size sheets of blank paper for mind maps(whiteboard would be preferred if we can borrow one for the three days), colored markers/sharpies, software to copy handwritten notes into electronic form (whiteboard with screen capture would be ideal if possible)



### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Get in touch with Rust!

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

### What will happen in your session?
The Rust project now has huge public presence in the programming world. We take pride in being approachable and would also like to be so during MozFest.

This space will provide:
* Q&A about Rust, why to use it and how to be involved
* A meeting space for tech interested people to get in touch with the Rust community
* A place for the curious. Never programmed? We don't mind, let's try!
* Some specialised sessions over the days, discussing specific community subjects like outreach and teaching

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
## What is the goal or outcome of your session?

We hope for multiple things, both outwards and inwards:

* To make people aware of what Rust is
* Get feedback about the project from people we usually don't meet
* Get in touch with people outside of the programming community
* Making people aware of how to get in touch with the Rust project
* Clarifying the role of programming languages and communities for the general public
* Discussing how Rust can be used to forward Mozillas mission

A projector would help, but is not strictly necessary. Something to write on, like a whiteboard or a flip chart would be very helpful. Power sockets would be great, but we can organise our own.

All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Lightbeam - an immersive experience

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** a514f33d-326f-47fa-a8da-084a3481d39c

**[ Session Name ]** Lightbeam - an immersive experience
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Princiya Sequeira
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Zalando
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @princiya




### What will happen in your session?
Lightbeam is a key tool for Mozilla to educate the public about privacy. Using interactive visualisations, Lightbeam’s main goal is to show web tracking, aka, show the first and third party sites you interact with on the Web.
In this session, the participants will get to interact with the trackers in the VR world thus creating an immersive Lightbeam experience. With animated transitions and well-crafted interfaces, this unique Lightbeam experience can make exploring trackers feel more like playing a game. This can be a great medium for engaging an audience who might not otherwise care about web privacy & security.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The ultimate goal of this session is for the audience to know and understand about web tracking. 
While web tracking isn’t 100% evil (cookies can help your favourite websites stay in business), its workings remain poorly understood. Your personal information is valuable and it’s your right to know what data is being collected about you. The trick is in taking this data and shacking up with third parties to help them come up with new ways to convince you to spend money and give up more information.  It would be fine if you decided to give up this information for a tangible benefit, but no one is including you in the decision.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
VR devices - Vive, Oculus etc.
At this point, I am not sure about this part :)


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ Session Name ]** Build a Fast & Dirty Chatbot
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Maya  Alvarado



**[ Additional facilitators ]** Charlotte,Fountaine


### What will happen in your session?
How do chatbots change the way that we interact with the web? Together we’ll design and build chatbots that allow people to access important but difficult to navigate online information. Through chatbots we are exploring how the design of the interface affects if someone can or cannot access the information they need, and the feelings they experience when doing so.
 
We’ll be using OnSequel, a free platform that allows people to create chat-bots that work on Facebook, Kik, Viber and Telegram. Either individually or in teams you’ll identify user needs and test using a particularly hard to navigate website. Your challenge, is to create a simple chat-bot which allows your defined users to access their necessary information.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To create chatbots which disseminate important but difficult to access information on a variety of different subjects. We’ll be learning to make simple chat-bots, and gaining an understanding of designing a different type of interface. 



### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 7406e350-e20b-46dc-9732-bd49611fb7d8

**[ Session Name ]** Web Zero to Web Hero - 3 stage digital literacy model for kids/youth/adults
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Gauthamraj Elango






### What will happen in your session?
During the session, I will walk through participants with "3 Stage Digital Literacy Model" that I have personally developed and currently working on with a regional level initiative. So far we trained over 300 students from under-priviledged community with this model. First stage covers, "Basics of Digital devices" that includes the computer, smartphone, tablets, etc., Second stage covers, "Basic digital skills to master the web" that includes email, search engine, browser, etc explained with real time examples for better and easier understanding along with a live demo. The third stage covers the introduction to Raspberry pi, Html and scratch programming. Learn more about 3 stage model here - https://goo.gl/XeERWj 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will gain basics of all digital devices - way it works, common aspects and differences among them. Participants able to effectively use newly gained digital skills - search engine, email, browsers, etc to find answers to their unknowns and critically evaluate the same for credibility. Participants learn to use Raspberry Pi, to create their first website using thimble and application using scratch - this develop their 21-st century skills and to take control of their life on the internet. Session will justify that English language barrier doesn't stop someone from effective use of internet. The gap between skills, qualification and opportunity can be addressed with digital skills. This video explain outcome from 3 stage model so far - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zidhKw6dGIc


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Will require projector and couple of monitors to connect Raspberry pi. If monitors are not possible couple of laptops will also serve the purpose through remote desktop. I am open to run this model as a exhibit or as drop-in session through out the weekend. 


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Our Data Bodies

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

body:
**[ UUID ]** 232aed87-3126-49f3-8bfd-35d78e081ede

**[ Session Name ]** Our Data Bodies
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Seeta Peña Gangadharan
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Our Data Bodies Project, London School of Economics


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Tawana Petty,Mariella Saba,Tamika Lewis,Virginia Eubanks


### What will happen in your session?
Many people concerned about algorithms, AI, and automated computer systems are thinking long and hard about privacy, discrimination, and ethical implications. But between talk of "surveillance capitalism," "fully automated luxury communism," and everything in between, public debate pays scant attention to the issue of data-driven technologies and marginality. In this session, we invite individuals to gain a deeper intersectional understanding of how data-driven systems impact marginalized communities' ability to access basic human needs. Based on experiences of individuals facing housing insecurity, job insecurity, criminalization, and more, participants will explore patterns and (dis)connections in order to develop new and creative practices for keeping all communities protected, together. 


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Our goal is to have participants:
1. Hear stories from members of marginalized communities as they confront data-driven systems in their daily lives
2. Connect these experiences to human rights and social justice considerations
3. Deepen human impact of data-driven technologies
4. Reflect and share their own experience and community stories, including how they relate or not to those of marginalized community members
5. Talking themselves and identify for himself how data driven systems are affecting their ability to live their lives    
6. Reflect upon existing strategies and develop new ones to confront data-driven technologies


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
None needed. But my team members will be traveling from the US and will need travel and accommodation support.


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Dating on the Open Web

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Evan Prodromou
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Fuzzy.ai
**[ Submitter's Github ]** evanp




### What will happen in your session?
I realize it seems trivial to people thinking only of press freedom, but romance and sexuality are a huge part of human existence. Almost all major dating sites are owned by a single company (Match.com). It's an area that requires privacy and gradual disclosure. Open dating systems are fascinating -- posting one or more profiles on the open web in a way that preserves your privacy but allows gradual disclosure and connection.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We will discuss how to implement open dating systems and see if we can kickstart a dating network.



### Time needed
less than 60 mins

**[ UUID ]** b4113da3-3e29-4787-ac15-ca09e9c31e26

### What will happen in your session?
Artificial intelligence in the hands of the few is a dangerous pattern for the future. How do we make the upcoming AI transformation a participative and distributed process? Can the act of creating and teaching AIs be something that everyone is involved in? Or are we destined for a future where only some people make AI, and the rest of us are observed and guided by them? We talk about techniques, patterns, and opportunities for democratizing AI.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants are informed about their options to create AI on their own, and may start working on AI projects.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector and WiFi
