title: The ActivityPub Network

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** 63072a00-3b9c-483b-90fe-e0b33bba574c

**[ Session Name ]** The ActivityPub Network
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Evan Prodromou
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Fuzzy.ai
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @evanp

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Chris Webber,


### What will happen in your session?
We'll give an overview of the W3C's ActivityStreams 2.0 social data standard, and its on-the-wire protocol ActivityPub. We'll talk about the state of implementation of ActivityPub in software like Mastodon, pump.io, GNU Mediagoblin and GNU Social. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want to give an indication of the state of decentralized social networks using ActivityStreams.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
It would help to have a projector and WiFi access so we can demo interactions on multiple servers.


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Strategies for building Consentful Technology
body:
**[ UUID ]** 1a73dbe8-fa94-4b7d-9fc0-d7178c84d316

**[ Session Name ]** Strategies for building Consentful Technology
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Dann Toliver
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Ripple Mapping Project
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @dxnn

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Una Lee,Lupe Perez


### What will happen in your session?
Modern technology allows people to communicate, share, and connect in profound new ways, but also exposes us to new risks too. As web makers, how can we provide those benefits while mitigating the risks? Consent culture, participatory design, community-focused functionality and cryptographic techniques point toward answers.

We’ll explore the process of designing systems and its connection to those risks. We know the consequences of building business products in isolation, but communication platforms are often created that way. This leads to shipping features that actively cause harm to users. We’ll discuss this predicament, share stories, dig in to causes, and look for solutions.

This proposal relies on Building Consentful Tech Zine to walk people through notions of consent: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1d9VgLD29kaNj-ux8RTDwWDiTcvwdRgsRXpEDpxzHfn4/edit#heading=h.ycv3f9cdo0pw (please request access)

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To highlight various ways people are negatively impacted by social technology and discuss techniques for building consentful technology that prioritizes people’s right to make self- determined choices about risk and harm. Participants should leave with a basic understanding of consent culture, participatory design, and risk-mitigating implementation techniques, and how to use those in their applications. We hope to expand the conversation and to leave everyone with  some food for thought for ways in which community and consent can start becoming foundational to building technology. The point is that we all have a stake to play in the path towards consentful web and tech! 




### Time needed
90 mins

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @epikhub

### What will happen in your session?
This session will be led by a tech mad Grand daughter together with her traditional book binding skilled grandmother. Together they will be exploring how to mix an ancient artform with a modern passion. Here you will learn how to make your own hand bound book in easy to follow steps using traditional tools and techniques merged with tech from LED's to device trackers so that you never again lose that logbook you MUST bring to school with you.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The objective of the session is to explore how an adult passion can be creatively shared with a young person through allowing that young person creative freedom to explore how and why anothers passion is connected to theirs and their heritage. In the case of this sessions the "Book binding Project" emmerged from a need to help Sabrina learn to value her notebooks that she constantly loses and forgets to bring to school with a culture of I can just buy a new one. By adding making your own books, an attachment is formed between the object created and the person and this attachment is then further re-enforced through sharing the new found skill and the making of the object mediated by a wider audience, our peers. 

### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A4 paper; lots of it

All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ UUID ]** 07fb1cdb-47d0-4c26-a05e-ce5ba5264a8b

**[ Session Name ]** Ad blocking as a privacy and security tool (and what we can do to make the ad industry better)
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Judith Nink
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** eyeo GmbH





### What will happen in your session?
1. Short presentation of the benefits of using an ad blocker in terms of privacy and security. 
2. exploring controversial statements, which shall be a starting point for the open discussion on which we’ll spend the rest of the time (around 50 minutes).
Ads not only promote products but also track users and can even infect them with malware. Through the use of different tracking mechanisms ads have the ability to make users almost fully transparent and thereby highly manipulable, which is contradictory to the upcoming General Data Protection Regulation.
Statements:
“Using an adblocker is not just a right, but a duty.”
Website providers must only use first party ads.
It's essential to make the website providers responsible for tracking and malware within ads. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
1. Share knowledge from different angles
2. Find a minimum agreement about what needs to be done, to enable the user to protect his/her privacy and the security of his/her devices when browsing the web.
3. Share ideas/find a strategy on how to (self) regulate the industry to provide the a better user experience and protection.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector.
Flip chart or white board would be a nice to have but are not mandatory.


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Tor in Town to protect your privacy

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

**[ Submitter's Name ]** Mehul Patel
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla India
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @rowdymehul




### What will happen in your session?
This initiative is all about educating people about the privacy and security provided by Tor Network and how they can also keep themselves anonymous from the open Surveillance web and other intelligence monitoring projects. We will teach about how it focuses on protecting the transport of data. 
In this session, we will share the following topics:
•	Safe Browsing Habits
•	Set Up Tor as a Proxy
•	How to Securely Share Files Using Tor
•	Coming Soon: Private Messaging With Tor Messenger
•	Tor for Android
•	Tor for iOS
•	How to connect to Tor Via Bridges and VPN?
•	Safe Tools for Whistleblowers
•	How to Contribute to Tor
•	Are there any alternatives to the Tor Browser?

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The result will be very clear, people will understand about the surveillance programs and how they can keep themselves out from it by keeping their identity anonymous. People can enormously explore new information which is not accessible to them in the normal Internet, they will also take interest to learn it because it is totally a different thing which is about to be shared in a Global level. Only 2% of Global Population know about Tor, so they will learn a lot and explore more and more about the security and privacy in today’s Digital World. Moreover our goal is to clear misconception that Tor is equal to dark or bad things on the web. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, Sticky notes, markers. Thanks. :)

60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 5b272cd6-a03b-4bb9-a309-c907bdf5c282

**[ Session Name ]** Trackers are creepy: What they know about you, and how you can fight back
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Bianca Danforth
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @biancadanforth

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Princiya Sequeira


### What will happen in your session?
Participants will learn through interactive activities about web privacy.

Part 1: We take several volunteers with one person as the trackee and everyone else as the tracker and make the analogy of online tracking as similar to being followed in real life.

Part 2: We pass around giant cards with fake ads that use embarrassing topics that trackers might know you have looked up.

Part 3: We ask people about common online searches and show the Lightbeam graph for the most popular related websites.

Part 4: We talk about what we are doing and what others can do to be a part of the online privacy/security movement.

Part 5: We have a Q&A with the audience.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We want people to be more aware of the risks that they take when browsing online and what they can do to protect themselves.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We would ask that you provide:
* Projector, projector screen, video dongles for Mac, ancillary video supplies
* Power extension cord
* 6x Poster Boards
* Several black permanent markers
* Two microphones, ancillary audio supplies

This proposal is related to another proposal by my co-presenter, Princiya Sequeira. If both are accepted, it would be very helpful if you co-located these sessions.

less than 60 mins

**[ UUID ]** 93a0bb2b-e25d-4c6c-8ac3-13e1816f4c58

**[ Session Name ]** The Dark Side of Smart Cities
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Neelima Sailaja
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Nottingham


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Lachlan Urquhart,


### What will happen in your session?
The session will consist of primarily three phases. An initiation phase, which introduces participants to the use of new technologies as part of smart city initiatives (smart street lighting, autonomous urban vehicles etc.). The second phase would be to work with the participants (using design probes provided by us) to develop scenarios that expose threats posed by internet of things and other technology that is used on a city-wide scale (e.g. hacked smart CCTV showing a married man walking into the red light district being used for ransomware; public hate speech being spread on smart billboards in racially/ethnically/religiously divided areas etc). The third phase would be an open discussion of the developed scenarios and potential solutions for addressing the challenges.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The overarching aim of the session is to encourage critical dialogue around the shift towards Smart Cities, the internet of things technologies enabling this transition and the potential crime and security risks they create. The conversations will start with outlining the threats and then move on to exploring possible solutions to address these. The discussions would prioritise how technology design solutions can address these concerns, providing new directions for inquiry in Situational Crime Prevention, Cybercrime Policing (from the desktop to the streets) and Security by Design.



### Time needed
60 mins

title: LET'S FLAG

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 4f9e88c3-9da6-43ac-89a2-4e02e723ac16

**[ Session Name ]** LET'S FLAG
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Una Rebic



**[ Additional facilitators ]** Metod Blejec


### What will happen in your session?
Let’s Flag is a session specifically designed for children and youth. It will focus on ideating and designing a Flag of the Earth. A brief introduction will include the history of flags, their meanings and basic principles of flag design. This will be followed by a warm-up exercise—world flag analysis. The practical part will comprise of thinking about attributes of our world and how we would present it (at an intergalactic congress for example). Through discussion our flags will be sketched while taking into account our world in all its diversity. In groups we will then design our flag symbolizing our vision of the world (positive, reactive, alarmed, etc.) and produce copies to take home.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This session aims to provide tools and methods that will aid participants in adopting basic principles of (flag) design (applicable broadly in visual design) and finding creative ways to render complex ideas by using simple graphic elements. With advancement of our visual literacy, we will be able to consider the role of visual language in the contexts where the use of verbal expression is limited or not possible. Notably, the goal of the session is also to critically think about the role of an individual and the society in relation to the world, its sustainability, ecology, our responsibility towards it, its past, present and possible futures.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
The session is tailored to suit the best possible learning methods and outcomes depending on the group and their age range. The session requires no electronics or specialised material. At the session we will need basic stationery: A4 copy papers, pencils, felt tip colour pens (sharpies), rulers, scissors, colored papers (as many colours as possible including black), glue and wooden skewers / chopsticks for final flag production.


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 1679b4bd-c913-49e8-b604-26d98fc7dc28

**[ Session Name ]** X-Men, Super humans or people with disabilities? Re-imagining disability through science fiction
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sean Gilroy
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** BBC


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Leena Haque, Samina Rafiq


### What will happen in your session?
The session will commence with a 30min presentation incorporating clips from popular Science fiction movies, demonstrating how disability is portrayed in leading characters positively rather than an impairment or weakness. Each group will then be given a famous film scene to work with and asked to reimagine the scenes main or key character with a disability or impairment. They will be allowed to creatively apply this change and finally present their changes to the group in any way they choose; as a script, a description of how they felt about the changes or even as a re-enacted piece filmed on their mobile devices.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The importance of perception portrayed by the modern media in popular culture and how this can influence what society believes or understands to be the truth.

Exploring how disability is portrayed in popular culture and the importance of accurate and truthful portrayal to foster acceptance and understanding in modern society.

To challenge existing cultural beliefs around disability, from one of impairment or limitation to one of ability and acceptance.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
The session will require a projector and audio system, together with A3 paper and markers for the creative participation section.  The projector and audio system will need to suitable for VGA/Audio and HDMI connection.


### Time needed
90 mins

title: An Introduction to neuro-hacking

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

title: Firefox <3 Tor Browser - The Art of Privacy

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 186fd615-8c4f-4e83-8c94-fa00d81bf618

**[ Session Name ]** Firefox <3 Tor Browser - The Art of Privacy
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ethan Tseng
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @ethantseng

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Tim Huang


### What will happen in your session?
One of Mozilla's principles of openness and participation:
"Individuals’ security and privacy on the Internet are fundamental and must not be treated as optional."

Based on this principle, Mozilla and the Tor Project have started an intense collaboration to make the Web more secure and more private.  We are adding the most advanced and valuable privacy features which can benefit both Firefox and Tor Browser users.

In this session, we will share the following topics:
- What is Tor and the Tor Browser
- How to protect your privacy by using Tor
- Anti-tracking protection technology
  - First Party Isolation
  - Browser fingerprinting resistance
- Upcoming advanced privacy features in Firefox
- The future of Web browser regarding privacy

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
We hope to achieve these goals by this talk:
- To awaken people to the threat to Internet privacy
- To break the misconception that Tor is equal to dark/evil things
- To educate people on how to protect their privacy on the Web
- To shed light on our vision of Web browsers in terms of privacy
- To advocate the accomplishment of the collaboration between Mozilla and Tor


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Required equipment:
- Projector


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 05939250-e492-4ed1-bc3f-ac3472e8513c

**[ Session Name ]** Building Consentful Tech zine
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Una Lee
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Ripple Mapping Tool
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @unalee

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Dann Toliver,Lupe Pérez


### What will happen in your session?
The zine will include:
- A definition of consent and consent culture
- How these concepts apply to technology
- Our definition of consentful tech
- Breaking down aspects of consent and fill-in-the-blanks style Q&A for readers to reflect on the tech they’re building/using/funding
--->Freely given — do users have a choice?
--->Reversible — is it possible and easy for users to revoke consent later on?
--->Informed — do users know the risks they’re being exposed to? How easy is it for them to learn about these risks?
--->Enthusiastic — how does the platform address discomfort?
--->Specific — are users able to consent to specific activities and decline others? Or is consent assumed to be blanket?
- Case studies and examples

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Begin conversations and reflections about consent and consent culture in technology
Give participants/readers a framework to evaluate how consentful a technology is
To serve as a resource for other sessions (DCTP session, Building Consentful Tech session, installation)



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Laptop with projector OR smart TV
Wall space 
Markers


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Digital Creativity in Primary Schools

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sarah Longfield
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** See Think Make


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Kim Stuyck,Fraser Morrison


### What will happen in your session?
We will talk about how we increased the digital creativity in Kaimhill School, Aberdeen in October 2016, through our Arts Award Takeover Week.  We will then run a hands on workshop demonstrating some of the apps and techniques used in the project, highlighting how these fit in both delivering Arts Award and the school curriculum.  Apps include DoInk, iMovie and Tellagami.  More info on our Takeover can be found at www.seethinkmake.co.uk/takeover.html


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To provide inspiration and a range of ideas for teachers, youth workers and other youth professionals to use in boosting people's digital creativity.

To increase the access for school children to the IT equipment available in schools: Several of the teachers in our Takeover school had never accessed the school's iPads and Chrome books until we ran our project, but now are using them regularly.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Whilst we'll strive to provide android alternatives, the main apps we would be using are apple only (e.g. Tellagami and DoInk.) so we would need iPads available - a minimum of 5 where a group could share if there's large numbers.  We can bring all other materials and will also bring our own iPad.  

If this isn't available please let us know and we could see if we could borrow some iPads up here to bring or could adapt the session to include a demonstration and then ideas generation exercises on paper/through conversation.


### Time needed
less than 60 mins

title: Mozilla - A role model for modern diplomacy

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** cd2d3561-d917-414c-9e6e-fed5a8141511

**[ Session Name ]** Mozilla - A role model for modern diplomacy
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Kristi  Progri
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Open Labs Hackerspace, Mozilla Tech Speaker
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @kristiprogri




### What will happen in your session?
How does technology affect nowaday's diplomacy and policymaking? Latter has been distancing itself more and more from the traditional communication model, switching over to a much more decentralized model. We will look into what implications this shift has had for foreign politics and policymaking with other countries. How do we perceive negotiations in this time and age and how does Free Software helps us Security and Privacy -wise in these aspects? Taking lessons from Mozilla and how its strategy aims to disrupt the way we use the internet so anyone can have equal open access. Why Mozilla can be a great role model for modern diplomacy, taking some lessons from Mozilla Advocacy and the Mozilla Manifesto.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of my talk is to show the audience that technology and FLOSS projects are effecting the international area and it's the right time to redefine the concept of the new diplomacy. The old-skool times where people could only imagine diplomacy as a high level gathering in a fancy office is now outdated. Say hello to online diplomacy and doing the same job online with a similar, if not more productive outcome traditional diplomacy has had.. Last but not least we will have a look at how the usage of a language can be a big powerplay in the diplomatic relationships of one country. 




### Time needed
less than 60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 86917a2f-667d-4fb3-8e21-b319f6e5d63f

**[ Session Name ]** Logging into Life: Working with Older Adults in Digital Literacy Education
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Meggie Lasher
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Horry Georgetown Technical College, Conway, SC, USA





### What will happen in your session?
Participants in this session will learn the basics of working with older adults in digital literacy education settings. Information society is now deeply embedded in digital life. For many older adults, they are often separated from this sphere of society based on a lack of skills using technology- in some ways, this is digital illiteracy. This session will help participants understand ways to facilitate learning, use approachable language, and employ practical examples to help those isolated from information society participate. There will be opportunities for small group work, sharing ideas and solutions, as well as real world examples. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of this session is to introduce participants to the lived experiences of those living in the digital divide. More often than not, individuals who are isolated from technology and information society are older, people of color, and/or speak a non-dominant language where they reside. Since technology is part of daily life, this exclusion prevents these individuals from having access to social, government, and educational services. Understanding how to offer the opportunity to learn about using technology gives this population the access and skills necessary to participate in the modern world. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I will need a projector, pens, and notepads.


### Time needed
less than 60 mins

**[ Session Name ]** The Dance Code
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Neha Lakhanpaul
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Arts Award Youth Network
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @nkl96




### What will happen in your session?

Simple workshops on how to create a dance. An insight into basic choreographic devices and movements; and the way this mirrors coding and developing technology, I.e. the idea of an achievable process open to all. Participants will be talked through simple dance structures and how to create motifs. They will then brainstorm inspiration and movements, create and put together motifs before putting on a small performance of their piece at the end of each session. 

A freestyle stage with 10 minute slots every hour so that individuals can show off their own skills and imagination to songs of their choice. Not only will this help to inspire others, but create recognition that dance is a universal language for all.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To illustrate the ever-evolving shape that technology has through dance and sound.  For each participant to have an understanding that any movement can be put together through a process which is very similar to the way in which we use code and imagination to create technology. These things go hand in hand. 
Performance will be encouraged to highlight that there is no right or wrong, and that once a dance is choreographed it can always be developed or changed.
The freestyle stage looks at promoting digital inclusion through the chance to show off and celebrate each other's individuality throughout the weekend.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Speakers - can be arranged to be brought from home.



### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: Magikcraft - Teaching Open Source Development in Minecraft

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

**[ Session Name ]** Magikcraft - Teaching Open Source Development in Minecraft
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Josh Wulf
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Magikcraft
**[ Submitter's Github ]** jwulf

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Prahlad Wulf


### What will happen in your session?
Participants can try out Magikcraft - a revolutionary system that integrates Minecraft with GitHub, NPM, and the web browser - allowing users to write code in their web browser, and run code directly from GitHub in Minecraft. 

They will go through a number of the learning scenarios in Magikcraft - an episodic, story-driven narrative. It's Dungeons N' Dragons meets Open Source coding in the world's most popular video game. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Coding is often taught as a solo activity - an individual at a keyboard, solving a problem. However, in practice it's a team sport, and the social coding aspect of it - including pull requests and community building - is as important as the technical aspect. Participants will walk away with a first-hand experience of this, and how to teach this from the very beginning.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A projector would be handy.

90 mins

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. body:
**[ UUID ]** e2d56bc6-0142-424e-9ffd-f300e27c3f0a

**[ Session Name ]** Why Does Computer Say No? Explaining Algorithmic Decisions
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Reuben Binns
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** University of Oxford
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @RDBinns

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Chris Kittel,Frederike Kaltheuner,Dana Polatin-Reuben,Michael Veale


### What will happen in your session?
Algorithmic systems are increasingly used to make important decisions about our lives; from the content we see on the web, to the job offers and credit scores we receive. But it’s not easy to understand why they make the predictions that they do, and if they learn from data which reflects social biases, they may reproduce them. In this interactive session, participants will learn how to open up algorithmic black boxes, explain their outputs, and discover their biases and quirks. We will try out a new explanation tool (LIME) which can explain the decisions of any classifier, whether the input is text or images. Using a web-based interactive environment, we will get hands-on with real datasets, models and code.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will have learned how to detect biases and explain the decisions of the machine learning models behind many of the systems that affect our lives. In groups, they will have investigated models trained on specific datasets to uncover how they work and their potential biases. Participants will come away with a greater understanding of how biases can arise in algorithmic systems, which will help them to advocate for responsible use of data in their communities, companies and platforms. Participants findings and insights will be shared and collected at the end of the session.



### Time needed
60 mins

For our collective sake
Let your passion create a story

The Youth Zone is like a poem—creative, unexpected, powerful. Join this space for youth leaders and their mentors who are creating art, technology and positive social change. From a Raspberry Pi-coded singing potato to our fireside chat on Internet health, come explore our collective tomorrow.

body:
**[ UUID ]** a372d0d0-7aa9-4a8c-8fb9-109e64469f2a

**[ Session Name ]** Create your own 'MozFest Monster' using Processing
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Elise Ainsworth
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Girls2Geeks
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @Girls2Geeks

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Neil Ainsworth


### What will happen in your session?
Using the little-known graphics programming language 'Processing', attendees will create a 'MozFest Monster' (or mythical beast) using functions and lines of code. They will make their monsters simply, with a variety of shapes and colours. Participants will be able to work together if they wish, or individually, but will have time to look at other attendees' work and learn from each other. Eventually, towards the end of the workshop, they will print out two copies of their digital artwork: one can be taken home for themselves; the other one will be put into a scrapbook called 'The MozFest Monsters Passport'. This will be a portfolio of all attendees' work, with their name, the monster's name and the Processing code.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To introduce participants to 'Processing' an innovative and user friendly graphics programming language based on Java. People will learn how to combine art, mathematics and computer science in a fun and friendly atmosphere.
After the participants have created their 'MozFest Monster' using the interface, they will print out a copy. This will be used to make the 'MozFest Monsters Passport', a portfolio of all work from the weekend. With the creator's permission, their code and an image of their monster will be put online, via my blog and Twitter account, for the internet community to see. I hope that this will be a fun way for them to share their creativity and new experience online.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
For this session I would require a number of Raspberry Pi computers and the necessary peripherals. In previous years, these have been provided in the Youth Zone via Pi-Top CEEDs. It would be ideal if the Raspberry Pi's had an internet connection (whether via a Pi 3 or Wi-Fi dongle), however this is not essential as the session could be delivered without the need to print, and instead I could do this later.
We will bring a portable printer to provide participants with a copy of their 'Mozfest Monster'.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** b8f40283-22e1-41a7-aad2-4c100f7b4792

**[ Session Name ]** Crypto Office Hour
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Franziskus Kiefer
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @franziskuskiefer

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Mark Goodwin


### What will happen in your session?
In the Crypto Office Hour we want to talk about all the crypto things underlying security mechanisms on the web. This includes, but is not limited to, the following.

What is Transport Layer Security (TLS)
Recent improvements in TLS and why it's necessary for a healthy internet while at the same time not sufficient
TLS 1.3 is awesome because it's avoiding many old mistakes/doesn't allow some of the old interception mechanisms.
Limitations of TLS and attacks
The role of end-to-end-encryption on the internet
Problems of end-to-end-encryption as seen in messaging apps such as WhatsApp.
How does the Web PKI work
Why is the Web PKI a mess?
What's the plan for fixing the Web PKI?
New developments in crypto
Challenges and solutions to secure crypto code.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is to increase the participants understanding of the mechanisms underlying most security and privacy mechanisms on the web.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Some paper and pens are probably sufficient.


### Time needed
90 mins

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. **[ UUID ]** 2ee586c1-e145-45c6-b16a-17e1d111cfc3

**[ Session Name ]** What’s the Opposite of a Troll?
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Meghan Lazier
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Vermont College of Fine Arts
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @meghanlazier

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Alex Pounds,


### What will happen in your session?
Why is it that we can easily identify a troll, but we cannot identify or name the exact opposite type of person online? This exhibition, created by participants during MozFest, will attempt to identify - and most importantly name - the opposite of a troll. Attendees will be encouraged to answer this question by building out a persona either online or offline - using a combination of links, images, videos and words that already exist on the internet or generated on the spot - that defies the behavior of trolls. The collected imagery and words will be projected throughout the festival to help attendees create consensus around the name and persona of an anti-troll.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
When we choose not to name a behavior, a belief or an aspiration, how can we call it out when we see it? It’s easy to ignore something without a name, but in divisive times, it’s important to celebrate the menches of the internet. This exhibit is an attempt to do just that - to name and identify more of the behavior we want to see online. Participants will be able to participate casually or spend more time thinking deeply about the topic. Youth are highly encouraged to participate.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
This session will require two outlets, a projector and two computers. I can provide the computers. I can also provide a projector, but it would be easier to borrow one if possible. Finally, I will need a wall or space to project on.


### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

**[ UUID ]** 6e9d768d-45eb-4bc4-8b3e-a10ca50755dc

**[ Session Name ]** Push: Help Build an Open Source Mobile News App
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Christopher Guess
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Reynolds Journalism Institute at the University of Missouri
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @cguess




### What will happen in your session?
I will introduce to the Mozilla community “Push”, an open source news app project. Push is specifically aimed at small and medium sized new organizations who can ill-afford the €100k it takes to build a fully custom iOS and Android app on their own. I will discuss the rationale for it, the use cases, and the decisions that went into it. For the journalists and editors in attendance I will demo its ease of deployment, its anti-censorship tooling, and discuss how to contribute support in development, design or using it in their own newsrooms. For developers and designers I will discuss how they can contribute and talk about the emerging community.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Push is a project that can significantly help small news organizations both cut costs and reach wider audiences. I hope to introduce this project to the wider world and to enlarge the community around it. Push has been a solo endeavor and with my current position at the University of Missouri’s Journalism School, I’ve devoted my work solely to developing and promoting the project. I hope to engage the Mozilla family and bring a wider perspective to the needs and development of Push. It’s been a labor of love, but it needs more than I can provide on my own.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, whiteboard or large post board and markers for brainstorming as well. 


### Time needed
60 mins

title: Fighting Fake News with Literacy Skills

milestone.title: Web Literacy
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The web is like a garden that we all plant and eat from. We need to consider what we sow as well as what, and how much, we consume. 

In the Web Literacy space, we’ll dig into the skills that help us read, write and participate on the web in a way that enriches both it and ourselves. Web literacy isn’t just writing Python—it’s knowing how to wield a search engine, how to craft a strong password and when our online activities are being tracked. 

Through hands-on workshops, participants will explore, make and play with the tools and technologies that form the fabric of the web. And through discussion and talks, we’ll invite our guests to reflect on, and improve, their relationship with the web. Our space will instill the skills and confidence in both young and old, students and teachers, to make the web a more vibrant, diverse ecosystem.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 0502fbfb-4739-4669-ada3-2429bbb6d1fc

**[ Session Name ]** Fighting Fake News with Literacy Skills 
**[ Primary Space ]** Web Literacy
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Sarah Morris
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Nucleus Learning Network 
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @secmorris 




### What will happen in your session?
In 2017 MisInfoCon brought together a diverse group, including technologists, educators, and journalists, to hack solutions to the current fake news epidemic. This proposed session hopes to bring the collaborative spirit of MisInfoCon to MozFest through a session where participants will hack a news and web literacy curriculum called Mission:Information. This curriculum seeks to empower youth to become strong consumers, producers, and distributors of media online. 

After engaging in a kinesthetic warm-up activity, participants will explore and brainstorm ways to further develop the curriculum. Participants will break into groups and use tools like Thimble to work on ideas that resonate with them, whether it is adapting the curriculum for younger learners or developing associated computer science lessons.  


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This proposed session aims to be highly collaborative, participatory, hands-on, and audience-driven. The main goals are, first, to introduce participants to issues and concerns related to fake news and misinformation. The second goal is to discover how Mozilla’s web literacy outcomes can support and enhance news literacy education. The third goal is to give participants an opportunity to explore, and consider ways to use, an open-source news and web literacy curriculum called Mission:Information. Finally, the last goal is to engage participants in a hacking session where they can contribute their ideas and skills and work on expanding and remixing the current curriculum. Participants will guide the direction of the session and determine the focus of their breakout working groups. 


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Attendees are encouraged to bring a personal device to this proposed session. I would need a projector and basic office supplies such as post-it notes and pens. 


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Let's Keep Our Chat Local

milestone.title: Decentralization
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
The year is 2027: Who owns the Internet?

In the dystopian version of 2027, the Internet is owned by a powerful few. Big tech corporations, select media companies and closed governments control the content on the Internet, the data that flows across the Internet and how people connect to the Internet. This dystopian future is closer than you may think.

On the flip side, what is the utopian version of the Internet in 2027? What future do we want to build? Where do emerging technologies like AI, mesh networking and Blockchain fit in? How do we ensure people are the most important part of the Internet?

Join us at Mozfest as we look into the future. Dystopian, utopian or somewhere in between—let’s explore the Internet of 2027.

Submit a proposal now - https://mozillafestival.org/spaces#Decentralization

body:
**[ UUID ]** ec2a13aa-5a61-4d7e-99bc-c5628c99e891

**[ Session Name ]** Let's Keep Our Chat Local
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ross Schulman
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** New America's Open Technology Institute
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @rschulman

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Matthew Hodgson,


### What will happen in your session?
New America's Open Technology Institute and the team at Matrix.org propose to provide the backchannel communications platform for MozFest. Instead of using Slack, WhatsApp, or other walled gardens, we will create a temporary, local Matrix server accessible to all participants.

In addition to the existence of the server on the local network. The physical server itself should be present to drive home the privacy, control, and power that decentralization brings. If technically possible we may also want to make the server itself mobile, so that participants can pick it up and carry it around.

Finally, we would like (if technically possible) to attach a visualization to the server demonstrating statistics such as number of connected users or frequency of messages sent.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
1) To spread knowledge of the matrix system and its abilities.
2) To demonstrate physically the nature of decentralization. Its ability to shift power, enhance locality, and benefit privacy.
3) To experiment with making matrix homeservers portable/carryable.



### Time needed
All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

title: On the Hunt for Meteorites: Narrative as a motivator for science exploration

milestone.title: Open Innovation

body:
**[ UUID ]** 5e37d1cd-15af-4f15-8015-66b34ec6e480

**[ Session Name ]** On the Hunt for Meteorites: Narrative as a motivator for science exploration
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Youth Zone


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Chris Bresky
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Adler Planetarium





### What will happen in your session?
This session is about framing scientific exploration as a narrative to lower barriers of entry for inexperienced makers.

A few months ago, a sonic boom shook the residents of the Midwest. A bright green fireball, a meteor the size of a minivan travelling at 38,000 miles an hour, entered our atmosphere and exploded with a force equal to a detonation of 10 tons of dynamite. Weather radar spotted the end of its journey as it splashed down in Lake Michigan. So now it’s there… still… and nobody, not even NASA scientists, know exactly how to retrieve it. 

We’ll rapid prototype solutions to this problem, with the money we don’t have, the knowledge we do have, and the innovation found through collaboration.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Students accustomed to school’s structured lessons can often be overwhelmed by the open endedness of creating in a makerspace. Each attendant will experience firsthand how connecting design challenges to a set narrative helps focus and free innovation. 

When students and educators can look to each other and ask, “How can we accomplish this?” and both be equally clueless about the answer, the only outcome is surprising innovation.

Each attendant becomes a part of our science team. They will gain the same sense of ownership over the project that each current student participant does. Since a hunt like this has never been attempted, every question asked is important, and every idea shared has value.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Scissors
Tape (scotch/duct tape)
Cardboard
Paper clips
Paper
Pens
Post-it notes
Small magnets



### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 707265ec-9efb-4303-954a-279c3b826f08

**[ Session Name ]** Cognitive Accessibility 101 - simple ideas for successful design for cognitive impairment
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Alastair Somerville
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Acuity Design
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @acuitydesign




### What will happen in your session?
A simple introduction to design for cognitive impairment (in physical and digital environments). The workshop will show some examples of the problems caused by cognitively inaccessible design and show a simple framework for designing for cognitive impairments.

The workshop uses experience from Alastair Somerville's work in museums and public realm design as well as clearly linking to the important digital standards work of the Cognitive and Learning Disabilities Accessibility Task Force of W3C.

The workshop will be interactive to allow for participants to provide greater insight from their own lived experiences and use an open session to use the design framework in practice.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goals of the workshop are:-
1) to provide a simple explanation of what cognitive accessibility is, who is affected and what bad design looks like.
2) to show a simple framework for successful cognitive accessibility design that can be implemented in any project.
3) to use open discussion to bring in personal experiences and show why personalisation matters.
4) to use exercises to show how to use the framework to solve some examples of cognitive inaccessibility.
5) to provide links to developing design resources at W3C and research organisations.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector
Post It notes
Pens
Flipchart paper


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** e258a589-d810-4c2e-802e-617c9b756ca5

**[ Session Name ]** VR for the People: How Anyone can Build a Virtual Reality Universe Fast and Free
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ann Marie Carrothers
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Foundation
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @annmarie123




### What will happen in your session?
Virtual Reality has already shown to have huge potential in almost every industry, from education and healthcare to journalism and activism. Unfortunately, the tools and resources to build in VR can be incredibly expensive and time-consuming, but it doesn’t have to be. Thanks to A-Frame, a simple, free and easy programming language, users can create and publish VR worlds in their browser no matter their tech skills or budget. In this session, attendees will learn how to create, build, and start incorporating the power of VR in their work immediately by learning the basics of A-frame and building a 360-degree tour. I will then demontrate ways in which VR can be helpful with journalism, activism, and education.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal of this session is to demonstrate how everyday people outside the tech industry can be creating VR using just a web browser. The dream for this presentation is to show off the incredible potential of WebVR as a platform to share learning experiences with the world and empower others to continue creating and/or teaching A-Frame + WebVR.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I will need a projector or monitor to demonstrate my presentation and how to create in VR using A-Frame. Other than that, I plan to bring materials, such as Mozilla VR goggles, for users to test their published projects.


### Time needed
90 mins

### What will happen in your session?
I want to show how with this open source, online platform we could digitize + 40.000 audios of a criminal investigation, plus 20.000 PDFs of elections forms & 16.000 PDFs of Senate Expenses.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GdgWWyKQvCo&t=333s
A terrorist attack with + 80 dead and 300 injured in a Jewish association. A federal prosecutor accused Argentina's ruling president of negotiating with Iran was found dead. 40.000 audios leaked and we classified them with Crowdata platform and published an app of 200 selected audios with federal impact.

One of the most important features that the platform has that other similar solutions don't is  ... TEAMS! Volunteers can gather under the badge of an NGO, University, non partisan organizations . Engagement increases and it gives accountability







### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Enlighten other mozfest attendants about the opportunities of investigation and engagement using the platform.

Crowdata was created by two Knight Mozilla Open News fellows. Manuel Aristaran and Gabriela Rodriguez

### What will happen in your session?
Postcard from Casa Jasmina is an IoT interactive installation using conversational UI. During the exhibition  user will control through a chatbot some of the basic devices within a home, trying to combine them and have a deeper user experience. Through archetypical shapes that represents the different functions of the house the user will have the opportunity to interact with a chatbot, express needs and receive a feedback that should be a message or a function. Six different wooden “cubes” represent basic home automation system. A fan for a temperature control system, an amplifier, a thermal printer for personal data specification, a sensor tower, a lighting system and a smart mirror. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
With Postcard from Casa Jasmina, we want to bring a 1: 1 prototype of Casa Jasmina, a smart home with a  completely open source technology. Postcard from Casa Jasmina wants to show how it will be possible to interact with the home and its technologies in the future. That's why the visitor can text with the individual units using a chatbot, a technology Casa Jasmina is developing to control the smart home.

For the installation is needed:
- ethernet connection with port and cable
- power plugs 
- table or base 180cmx90

All weekend, as an installation, exhibit or drop-in session

body:
**[ UUID ]** 7a09ee0c-a533-4ed9-b5d7-518a6fbd1549

**[ Session Name ]** Setting the Conditions for Open Leadership
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Decentralization


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Chad Sansing
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Foundation
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @chadsansing

**[ Additional facilitators ]** TBD


### What will happen in your session?
In this hands-on, participatory workshop, participants will use a collaborative, social game design experience to reverse engineer the cultural and material conditions necessary to foster open leadership. Working in groups, participants will re-purpose and up-cycle generic game pieces into new games that are fun and fulfilling for each teammate. After that, they'll discuss and share the decisions and processes that made their game-designs successful. With the remaining time, participants will sketch action plans to bring those processes back home. Drawing on Mozilla's Open Leadership Training Series and its expertise in teaching about the open web, session facilitators will help participants move from play to reflection to action in planning next steps for developing open leadership in their projects and organizations.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Participants will leave knowing how open leadership looks and feels. They will also leave with concrete next steps they can take to introduce and implement open leadership habits and norms within their projects and home organizations. Finally, participants will be able to offer the workshop to their home organizations thanks to its highly adaptable and reproducible nature.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I will ask my manager for a small materials budget; I anticipate needing paper, cardboard, scissors, tape, markers, dice, game pieces, game boards, play money, and other easily sourced, inexpensive crafting supplies.


### Time needed
90 mins

**[ UUID ]** c56faedd-39d6-437e-b659-7c1251d2b8d6

**[ Session Name ]** AI Voice Assistants and the Web
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Privacy and Security


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Peter O'Shaughnessy
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Samsung
**[ Submitter's Github ]** poshaughnessy

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Diego González,TBC, we're hoping to have a collaborator from another organisation too


### What will happen in your session?
The session would start with an introduction/proposition: could 'AI' voice assistants (Cortana, Bixby, Google Assistant, Siri etc) help power our interactions with the web?

We would introduce ways that assistants are already commonly integrated with browsers, e.g. search. What if they could also navigate, read content and fill out forms for you? If your assistant and browser were integrated further, would that be useful? Concerning? Could they bring accessibility benefits beyond current screen readers?

We would ask participants to group together and sketch ideas. What kind of commands and interactions would their ideal assistant allow? How would it protect your privacy? We would ask the groups to share their thoughts, collate the themes and address questions via discussion.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Ideally we would come away with a set of ideas, designs and remaining unanswered questions, covering how AI assistants can/should interact with web browsers. We will share the results for further discussion after the event. For organisations developing assistants, this would help us to take into account web users’ needs and concerns.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Just the office supplies (paper, pens, post-it notes) should be fine.


### Time needed
60 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** b4a9eabb-e47b-4941-ab1b-4f81e5769604

**[ Session Name ]** Should the internet have its own Universal Period Review? 
**[ Primary Space ]** Decentralization
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Bronwen Robertson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Small Media





### What will happen in your session?
The Universal Period Review is a unique process which reviews the human rights records of all UN Member States. Could we imagine a future where the process is used to support online freedoms as well? Although underutilised at the moment, the UPR already provides a framework within which we can lobby governments to change the way they regulate and control the internet and the lives of citizens who use it. We’ll lead a participatory discussion on using the UPR to lobby governments to change their policies on internet regulation, and encourage our participants to formulate a series of recommendations to put to countries at the UN!

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
After we give an overview of the UPR process, and show how it’s been used in the past to recommend changes to the approaches governments take to regulation and control of the internet, we’ll set up some participatory activities to get our attendees thinking about recommendations that can be proposed during upcoming UPR sessions at the UN. We’ll use our data insights (our research team works on the UPR, see upriran.org for example) to show good countries to target for support, and which countries need to be targeted to change. We’ll draft a series of recommendations together, along with an outline for a UPR advocacy plan for a number of countries with upcoming UPR sessions. 



### Time needed
60 mins

title: DATA4CHANGE: Visualizing Human Rights

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

body:
**[ UUID ]** f688758d-9381-4c59-a2f7-c8ec9526da6b

**[ Session Name ]** DATA4CHANGE: Visualizing Human Rights
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Bronwen Robertson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Small Media


**[ Additional facilitators ]** Stina Bäcker,Surasti Puri


### What will happen in your session?
We will introduce DATA4CHANGE through a mini version of one of our data visualisation workshops. We will bring datasets from our D4C alumni (eg. sexual harassment in Egypt, corruption in Lebanon, LGBT rights in Uganda), which are published on our GitHub profile, and visualise them, telling a story using RAW (open source).  First, participants will form teams, ensuring a balance and range of skills and backgrounds through a brief (and fun) participatory activity. Then, we’ll give teams briefing documents for a dataset and project, and our moderators will move around the teams to provide support and guidance. We’ll give training on visualisation tools, and create final products that can be shared with the HROs that provided the initial data.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
To work with data collected by human rights organisations to create advocacy and campaigning materials that they can use in their work. To introduce participants to the DATA4CHANGE alumni network, and encourage active participation beyond MozFest. To talk about the challenges in working with human rights data (ethics, privacy, risk involved) and to showcase the amazing work of our D4C alumni network, many of whom are working in incredibly risky environments, and in most cases not able to access ‘free and open’ internet. Our goal is to understand how we can encourage people to support HROs across the world with their skills and time to achieve core advocacy goals.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
We will only need a projector, and will bring all other equipment ourselves. 


### Time needed
90 mins

title: Kill all the Orcs, Hack all the Things

milestone.title: Privacy and Security
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Do you feel safe online?

Sometimes, online security can feel unattainable. State-sponsored surveillance, theft of personal information, trolls arrogantly abusing others—this has become normal. And every day, many of us trade personal information for convenience.

It’s time to flip the script. Not everyone knows how to install a VPN or use encryption—but everyone should feel safe online. Can we imagine a future where manufacturers respect our safety by default when they build products? Where governments take steps to protect us? Can we find fun, new ways to engage our friends and neighbours around these issues?

At Mozfest, we’ll build, teach and play with these new approaches to Privacy & Security. Let’s put safety first.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 2115d390-a2c6-466c-aaf6-5fe4f24d6e37

**[ Session Name ]** Kill all the Orcs, Hack all the Things
**[ Primary Space ]** Privacy and Security
**[ Secondary Space ]** Web Literacy


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Chad Walker
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** This talk would be 100% unaffiliated with my employer, Target Corporation.
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @cryptomancer-actual




### What will happen in your session?
I could do a few things.

I could give a talk that is an overview of how I have been using the tabletop roleplaying hobby as a means for security/privacy education and advocacy, both in the first game I released (Cryptomancer), and a forthcoming game about network resiliency in the face of Internet shutdown, inspired by the Egyptian Arab Spring.

I could also run a few sessions of Cryptomancer for players. I could see myself running a morning session and an afternoon session (about 3 hours each) for about 5 players, different players each time, in a break-out room or something.

I could also permit Mozilla to give every single attendee a free PDF copy of Cryptomancer.


### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
1) To demonstrate that security/privacy stuff can be outrageously fun in the right context.
2) To demonstrate that security educators/advocates can get a lot mileage out of playing in the hobby/genre spaces people already occupy.
3) To give folks ideas they can apply to their security interactions in their organizations and communities.
4) To continue to demystify tabletop role-playing games, and show how they are a totally normal, banal, and entertaining way to pass the time, tell stories, and share positive memes.
5) To get outrageous free press. :P


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
For a talk, I'd like to borrow someone's laptop to present slides.

For game sessions, I'd need a table that can fit 6 people comfortably in a break-out room that's not super loud (i.e. not in a public hall).


### Time needed
60 mins

title: The Upside of Down: Personal stories of failure, reinvention, and challenges faced by innovative people & open communities

milestone.title: Open Innovation
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
An open web provides the opportunity to publish and invent online without permission. To keep it this way, the technologies used to run the web should remain transparent and understandable.

Open Innovation is a space for challenging and learning about open source, open projects and growth on the web. We’ll investigate the challenges to open production (misinformation, draconian copyright) and the values of open creativity (working open techniques, tools and tactical transparency). The space is programmed as a highly-interactive platform for producing and protecting the principles of the open web. Join us in evolving our epically-open online world.

body:
**[ UUID ]** 2ca08eec-b12c-4952-a4b6-b49ddeb8006b

**[ Session Name ]** The Upside of Down: Personal stories of failure, reinvention, and challenges faced by innovative people & open communities
**[ Primary Space ]** Open Innovation
**[ Secondary Space ]** Digital Inclusion


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Danielle Robinson
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** Mozilla Science / Code for Science & Society
**[ Submitter's Github ]** @daniellecrobinson

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Teon Brooks, PhD


### What will happen in your session?
People will sign up to tell their short (5 minute maximum) personal stories of failure, reinvention, and innovation. We want to create a welcoming, honest place to talk about the challenges faced by open communities, people working openly, and innovative projects. Not all stories will wrap up cleanly. Not all stories will have happy endings. Sometimes things don't work out. Sometimes things get messy. It's all part of the process and we've all been there, so let's talk about it! We have a few people committed to speak now, others will be able to sign up via our GitHub repository (https://github.com/daniellecrobinson/The-Up-Side-of-Down). At the event, time will be reserved for people to speak on the spur of the moment. 

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
Innovation is messy. The myth of the lone innovator that western culture embraces is that of a man alone in his garage. He overcomes challenges and eventually finds success. But this narrative is flawed, exclusionary, and discounts the value of community. The goal of this session is to provide an open forum to talk about challenges faced by innovators and innovative communities. We'd like to showcase stories of ideas that didn’t quite work. Stories of spectacular failure. Stories of reinvention. Stories of communities facing real world issues. By creating a supportive environment to talk about challenges, we can bust the “lone innovator” myth, surface stories from the community, and build personal supportive connections within the innovator space.



### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
A microphone would be great!


### Time needed
90 mins

body:
**[ UUID ]** 7a8a64f5-c05e-47d9-b16c-f517298a0831

**[ Session Name ]** Hacking on games using Thimble and more! :D
**[ Primary Space ]** Youth Zone



**[ Submitter's Name ]** Ryan Warsaw

**[ Submitter's Github ]** @ryanwarsaw




### What will happen in your session?
Attendee's will spend the initial 30 minutes reviewing basic concepts, as well as good etiquette and how to safely and responsibly reverse-engineer and modify games for themselves! After that, we'll spend 60 minutes hacking on some pre-built demos to create some awesome experiences. 

Changes to the demos (of which there are three) can be seen in real-time, we will be using open source tools such as Thimble, A-Frame, Voxel.js and more! As well as Minecraft for Pi. Each demo will range in sophistication, so that everyone regardless of programming experience can have a fun and enjoyable time.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
The goal is not only to get people excited about programming & game development, but to also have the confidence to take their skills and create their own "mod" as commonly referred to by the game development community. Modifying games is a very rewarding experience, and very popular in games such as Minecraft.


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
I would need access to a Projector that has either an HDMI, or Mini-Display connection port. I would also need temporary access to 10-15 computers (Pi Tops, Laptops, Tablets w/Keyboard, etc). As well as some paper & pencils.


### Time needed
90 mins

milestone.title: Digital Inclusion
milestone.description:
**Space Description**
Imagine an Internet that truly puts people first—where individuals can shape their own experience and are empowered, safe and independent.

The Digital Inclusion space explores ways of increasing equity of access and participation across the web. We’re addressing restrictive infrastructure and finding ways to overcome the cost of technology; celebrating linguistic diversity and sharing ways to make the Internet more representative of the planet’s many cultures; and developing solutions to make all people safer and empowered in their digital lives. As you move through this space, you will see how an inclusive web truly benefits humanity.

body:
**[ UUID ]** fb3e5483-3d62-4700-8f90-b448b3d3f28a

**[ Session Name ]** Open Curriculum Development For Multimedia Documentation of Endangered/Marginalized Language
**[ Primary Space ]** Digital Inclusion
**[ Secondary Space ]** Open Innovation


**[ Submitter's Name ]** Subhashish Panigrahi
**[ Submitter's Affiliated Organisation ]** OpenSpeaks
**[ Submitter's Github ]** psubhashish

**[ Additional facilitators ]** Prateek Pattanaik,


### What will happen in your session?
As half of the world’s native languages are dying, a vast majority of the native language speakers do not get to access information or contribute to the knowledge commons in their own languages. This largely affect the digital inclusion equilibrium. There is an urgent need to digitally-document certain aspects of a language. This session will include demonstration of Open Educational Resources, Open Source software, and Open Datasets that are currently being developed to specifically document endangered/marginalized languages, create open multimedia archives, digital tools like spoken dictionary, text-to-speech and lead to brainstorming on the topics related to digital inclusion using open innovation and web literacy.

### What is the goal or outcome of your session?
This session will focus on the following outcomes:
* Detail about what diversity and inclusion gaps currently exist for many marginalized language speakers when it comes to access to knowledge and contribution to the knowledge commons in their native languages; and how they impact on the open knowledge economy
* Providing a foundation-level knowledge and open toolkits (Open Educational Resources, Open Source software, Open Datasets and methodology) on how to build multimedia libraries
* Sharing about ways to build digital-accessibility solutions like text-to-speech and speech-to-text from the multimedia-libraries
* Brainstorming to grow a community to develop aforementioned multilingual resources


### If your session requires additional materials or electronic equipment, please outline your needs.
Projector, microphone-speaker setup and office supplies (paper, pens, post-it notes)


### Time needed
60 mins
